reviews.review: Best place for shopping in Lisbon!. Trendy, traditional, cool, diversified and with amazing architecture, this is the best area in Lisbon for shopping and tasting some of the best flavors of the Portuguese cuisine!

Life, fun , shops, restaurants , art all of good things are there. Amazing for walk , shop take a coffee , have a good meal. Te Opera , elegant people . all you can find in the most elegant quarter of the city

Nice for a walk around. ... This is a kind of touristic must-do. Is the commercial get together point of the city and has a nice atmosphere.
A couple of nice shops to do and places to take a coffy and see people from all the world going up and down...
Very cool area of Lisboa. The Chiado is upscale and a great place to wander about in the haphazard streets. Good shopping & good places to eat.

Amazing time there!. Breathtaking architecture. We couldn't stop staring at the buildings. There are shops, restaurants and bars. Nice for a walk if you are not in a hurry because it will surely keep you busy for a long time. Don't miss it!

Restaurants in the Chiado. This is the place to eat. Tons of cool restaurants in the Chiado. Lots of the shopping is more geared towards the big multinational corporations but you can find some local artists and shops if you look hard enough.
Shopping and entertainment. Great shops with cafes along the way. A relaxing and accessible trip through key shopping spots. Agreeable shops with excellent value.

Pleasant area. Nice area of Lisbon, quite cosmopolitan, full of colour and passion, you will find in some evenings live music from street artists, of course the area is not a cheap as other areas of Lisbon, but it does worth a visit, and a stop in particular to "A Brasileira" cafe.
chiado. Chiado is a place full of shops , nice restaurants and coffee shops.It is near Rossio and walking distance from bus metro and taxi stand.

beautiful section of Lisbon. Upper end, classier, of Lisbon. Full of restaurants and Cafe's and Theaters. If shopping is for you, there is a six floor mall called Armazens Do Chiado. From here it is an easy walk downhill to the lower section, the Baixa

Chiado full of life day and night. Chiado is one of the Lisbon´s spot with a great variety for day and night life, with Largo de Camões always busy with starting walk tours, live concerts and events along the year and a meeting point for the surrounding famous night life places either in Bairro Alto or Cais do Sodré.
have a seat. and watch whats going on. pricier than other places in town but this is where the people are from all over the world. recommended meutermedia
Handy to public transaport and not too lively. A very pretty area with nice restaurants and bars. There is a reasonable night life but not as raucous as some areas

A special old world charm. A must visit. Live music food and a great vibe. I can spend hours there and normaly do.
Check for the tripadvisor sticker when you decide on a restaurant

Chiado is so lovely..... Our apartment was in the Chiado area of Lisbon right on Miseracordia. Many things to do and see. We visited the lovely Rua Garret for shopping and espresso/pastries. We also visited the Convento do Carmo which is so incredibly beautiful. From the convent you can access the Elevador de Santa Justa without waiting in the incredibly long line at the bottom. You can access Rua Augusta which runs from Parco Commercio to Parco Rossio and all the restaurants and shopping in between. Also, you can easily access Liberdade Avenue. In my opinion Chiado is the best place to stay in Lisbon. You can walk everywhere from here!

Well, they might call it down-town, but not bad !!. Our guide told us that Chiado Baixo as they call it, was not the best place in town and that food was expensive and of bad quality. I believe that, with tripadvisor's advice, you can find really nice place and a decent plate of food. Also, there are a lot of activities at week-end (markets, etc) and shops are open everyday of the week (only big shopping malls on Sunday).
To visit!. Another great place to visit in Lisbon, full of shops, restaurants, bars, but also museums. You have to experience it!

Lovely area in the middle of the city. Central, classy, lots of places to sit and have a drink and watch the world go by. Next to Bairro alto for late night drinks and to Baixa for shopping, 5 minutes walk to the river

Smart area. On the way to the Barrio Alta, a smart shopping and eating area. Many churches and squares. The Metro station Baixia-Chiado has an entrance in both places. The escalator link from the depths of the metro in Baixia to Chiado is quite something!
The best little quarter in Lisbon. This area has it all. A ruin, great shops and restaurants. If you are in Lisbon this is the area to hang out!
Great shopping!. A great area for a stroll and visiting shops. Treasures can be found among the usual tourist-y stuff.

Chiado is the perfect place to stay in Lisbon. My husband and I just returned from a wonderful 10 days in Lisbon, which was our first visit there. We had an amazing vacation. We rented an apartment in Chiado through an online service and it was a perfect location from which to base our stay. We were able to walk throughout the city given the central location of Chiado, From our rental we were a 10 minute walk from the Time Out Market, 10 minutes from Castelo S Jorge, 5 minutes or so from Barrio Alto and about 10 minutes from the river. In addition, there are many, many wonderful restaurants and bars and places to shop in Chiado. We hope to return and would most definitely view Chiado as the place to stay next time.
Happening area. Lots of places to eat, drink and shop. Great area to walk around and get a good feel of Lisbon's charm day and night.

Loads of possibilities. Chiado offers many restaurants with great food. There is a metro station in its heart and you can get around the small lovely streets looking for a restaurant to catch your eyes and belly. The neighbourhood is usually full of people, but it is a very nice environment for tourists.

Weekend visit. This is a lovely area. Central for most attractions. Nice to walk around we felt very safe here. We stayed in the dream chiado apts which were right in the middle of everything the staff were very helpful and we could leave are bags there on the last day add we had a late flight. If you stay here you silk be close to the elevator which is a must see attraction. It is ticked away in the middle of the town but is great to see. We also aye in the Chinese buffet next to it which was okay. From the loft you can see a church go to the bar there its lovely just to chill out.
Cool Neighbourhood. Good food, cute streets and fun bars. I really enjoyed this little neighbourhood. I'd recommend going for an easy afternoon of strolling and exploring.
Lively place at night. It is a place that sure to be interesting at night, with some musician play music at the restaurants. They are playing native and indigenous tunes which add life to the night.
Wonderful Area to visit. This square is wonderful for a visit. Day and night. South and North connecting streets have wonderful restaurants and monuments in them. You never get bored here

Seems to be like the Joordan Area in Amsterdam. I would have stayed in this area, had I known the city better. Seems to be the "hip place' with shopping, lots of restaurants, etc. Streets are steep so not good if you have walking issues. You can find local Portuguese items here also.

The core of Lisbon. If you are in Lisbon this is the place to be. No matter if you are young, old, alone or with famaly.Just to walk around, have a drink or a meal. And the best is that all happen almost 24hr a day Almost

Great area. Do visit this area. It's full of beautiful buildings and great shops and cafes. Sit outside In the evening and enjoy the music and street entertainers. You can also catch Tram 28. Instead of going to Alfama take the tram to the cemetery and walk back.

Amazing!. We had such a great time here.Saturday nights are especially good. Walk around a find those small lanes that has lines after lines of bars. People are out of the street drinking, dancing, chatting. It's a wonderful party atmosphere. And it is completely safe just like the rest of Portugal. MUST GO!

Chiado, Lisboa . This is THE district to stay in!
Local culture, Fado, music and dance, central location with back streets abounding in local shops and people.
Easy accessible from Metro, Chiado welcomes the visitors with open arms. Enjoy it
A LOVELY AREA. We spent most of our time in Chiado. Lovely restaurants and shops and easy from our hotel. It seems to be the most upmarket area in Lisbon
One of the best neighbourhoods. This is without a doubt one of the best neighbourhoods for shopping, eating and enjoying the relaxed lifestyle of Lissabon.

My neighborhood. I chose Chiado to stay in for it's wealth of interesting things to do and see in a relatively small physical area. Nevertheless, there are plenty of hills and stairs - and views to go with them. It is a seemingly safe area, but watch for pickpockets on trams especially.

Nice place to enjoy night life, lovely walks. Visit this region if you are interested in exploring neighborhoods for a lovely stroll looking for the perfect restaurants and having a relaxed time. One will find lots of sightseeing options close by - the views of Sao Jorge castle from here are amazing.

upscale, trendy neighborhood. A fun neighborhood, upscale, trendy, great food, drink, and entertainment - a must see in Lisbon. Always a happening area - morning, afternoon, evening, and into the night.
Popular and touristy. Has to be experienced at least once, but too touristy ! Part of a visit to Lisbon though. Full of shops. Traffic everywhere, not easy to walk around.

Beautiful. This is a very beautiful section of Lisbon, lots of great shops, sites, and you get a feel for 'real' Lisbon life. The metro is easy to navigate, the people are friendly and helpful, and the atmosphere is vibrant while not being noisy and wild.
Real Old Lisbon. Stayed there for a week. Loved the atmosphere and restaurants bars and the little park on top of hill.
Beautiful Place. Just one of the many beautiful places in Lisbon, great to walk around, beautiful in the day and stunning at night
Must visit!. There are lot of different option in this area. From shopping, to restaurants, grabbing a quick snack, ice cream, etc, etc. It's very central as well. A must see!

Must visit. You will walk around all day but this place has so many things to offer that even 1 day isnt enough. Do not miss santins ice cream here. Amazing place to shop all the high fashion brands and even the local stuff. Definitely a must do.
Chiado Area. Lots of shopping, restaurants and local transportation. Also close to other site seeing attractions and the sea.

Modern area, shopping all over the place. This is centralized area that you can't skip if you are going through the city by foot. Many stores, many restaurants, squares, cafes. Nice to see, nice to go through.
Pleasure. A central area with a lot of nice cafes, drink beer and shops. Magical atmosphere and very lively, especialy afternoon and evening.
Central park of the main drag from AV Liberdade to the sea front.. Pleasant area to browse the local scene and includes several interesting government buildings and churches.

Modern Lisbon . Our third visit to Chiado, the first with a toddler in a stroller.If you can manage the steep and narrow streets, navigate the rough seas of cobble stone and calçada then you'll have some real quality time.The choice of food outlets, the proximity of everything around you is just comforting.You can enjoy a refreshment or a full meal while the little ones can watch side shows and people go by. Or even better, wait for the 28 tram and count the countless toctoc rides (noisy ones) go by.Chiado is the busy trendy chic town, better views are evening to midnight with a real friendly atmosphere.My favorite part of town, my Chiado.

The core for tourists. Robust and active part of Lisbon. Most tourists come and stay in this area or around. Full of named shops and touristic restaurants and cafes. I love the area and I own an apartment there too

Beautiful heart of Lisbon. Chiado is an amazing old town/new town district offering amazing food, cafes, art galleries, live music and historical sights. An absolute must visit and if possible, stay in Chiado as it is central to everything.
Meet the 1700´s. Meet the 1700´s and what happens when you let people loose on a pretty place. Great shops, too many drug dealers with fake drugs, Great sights.
Beautiful neighbourhood.. Very nice neighbourhood, pleasant walk just make sure you wear comfortable shoes! Even in hot days there's a breeze and many terraces to cool down
Tourist friendly without being touristy.. It felt like I was exploring a "real" European city without the kitschy extras that seem to invade touristy areas.

Absolutely delightful to stay here . Want romance? I walk through the cobble stone streets to one of the beautiful parks. They all have beautiful flowers, often monuments, statues, fountains, and little cafes for a beer or espresso.
Want party? So many great restaurants, bars and establishments with live music.
I hope to return to this lovely vibrant neighbourhood!

Simply put, the best restaurant in Lisbon. This place. Small and cozy restaurant with incredible staff and out-of-this-world food. Try the steak on the stone and bacalhau or polvo à lagareiro. I promise it will be worth your money.
Love the Streets. It's amazing walking the streets of Chiado, it's a very full of life with lots of shops and cafes and it also gives you quite the workout!

A pretty revival. After a horrible fire which destroyed this part of town, Chiado was literally abandonned for many years until the City started a great restauration. Since then, the area has been dramatically improving, with new fancy shops, restaured old cafés, restaurants and other eateries and all the old residential buildings beeing lavishly restaured and transformed in luxuary appartments. Ideal for expensive shopping and to hang around the old spots which gave birth to the most famous late 19th century and early-mid 2àth century litterature movements
Nice!. Very nice place with direct access to beach !A must see if you are in Lisbon. Reminds me a bit place Massena in Nice.

Great Shopping and Food. Some great retailers in the higher-mid-range. Also great, small restaurants littered throughout the historic neighborhood. Several wine and charcuterie bars, as well as gorgeous old churches.

Great walking area. This is an amazing part of the city where you can walk around and experience the old commercial vibe that has been refurbished recently after the great fire. You will find some great bargains if you are into shopping. A must do trip while in Lisbon

Mitical place . It's a beautiful place one of the best places to visit in Portugal since it's very historical and show the buildings of Portugal and arquitectural design of the old buildings of Portugal I like wort the visit

Nightlife, Shopping & Dining. Chiado has it all in the heart of Lisbon. It is easy to get there and to travel to other attractions from there. It is full of nice place to dine and wine, and there is plenty of shopping. Definitely a place to see. If you're a non-smoker though, this is a place to be prepared to find lots of cigarette buts and people smoking on the street. Besides that, it is fun.

Nice ! . I have the idea that Buenos Aires is like Chiado - but I never went ! - I'd love the shopping venue mixed with souvenir shops, restaurants... You feel that you can breathe ! Unlike Saint Michel in Paris : Chiado is open with large streets, the sky is everywhere.

Fun place. Get lost in these historical streets. Great ambiance and don't miss the Fernando Pessoa statue sitting in front of a restaurant. One of my favorite poets, it was for me a very pleasant surprise.
Lovely area. Booked a charming flat here and found it the perfect location to explore Lisbon, lots of character- bars and cafes
A popular district to shop and eat when you are in Lisbon. You won't possibly miss Chiado when you are in Lisbon because it's a popular district for locals and tourists.
Nice and ecletic. Love it. Lots of local history and great architecture, old building and places, stone streets.... great

Good neighborhood to walk around with a number of good museums. We enjoyed walking around Chiado. There were a number of museums on our Lisbon Card in this district. We particularly enjoyed the modern art museum.

Great ambiance.. This upmarket shopping area in Lisbon is a frequent stop-off for anyone visiting the city. Having a bica (espresso coffee) and pastry at the Brasileira restaurant is an institution in Lisbon.
Stayed in Chiado Hotel. Very nice hotel, excellent situation, close to everything. Breakfast is very good, and service is excellent.

Elegant shops, peaceful corners. This is definitely the most elegant area in Lisbon. There are many elegant and stylish shops along the main street, Rua Garrett. There are many theatres too.Praca Luis de Camoes is a nice square with kiosk.In the past this area was inhabited by priests, monks and hence there are many churches to visit.If you do not want to walk up to the Chiado, use the escalators from the Baixa area.
Best shopping district . Chiado was mine and my husbands favorite place in Lisbon. Fantastic shopping, and a great place to have a drink some lunch.

Shops and Restaurants . The main shopping and tourist area of central Lisboa it's full of people all the time after 11am as most of the shops and restaurants starts trading from 9:30 or 10am in the morning. It's wonderful area with the sea views and there are plenty to do as well.

Visit at bight. The 28 team takes you through here but go back in evening for dinner. It's very vibrant and entertaining. It has Live music and lots of places to eat. It's a great place to see at night as well as day
Central location. Very hilly but great spot near cafes, fado, shops & tours. Great cafes for breakfast.Top of the hill so be prepared to walk
A place to be. Chiado is the hart of Lisbon. During the day or night, this place is full of life...To visit and enjoy...It was also lot of old buildings and very romantic to be.

Amazing streets and nice stores. A lovely place or i should say a shop makers Heaven. This place have an amazing architecture and full of stores around a must to pass a day shopping. Also full of restaurants and bars. Very near Bairro Alto and Baixa Pombalina a must go.

The beating heart of Lisbon. Its a really appreciated and popular district in Lisbon, the most beautiful in my opinion.You don't get bored of walking around since its very animated and entertaining. For the shopping amateurs also, you'll find there what you're looking for.The thing that makes it Very Good and not Excellent is the unsafely feeling you get when drogue dealers ask you to buy their commodity, especially at night.

Chiado. As one of the distinct districts, I found Chiado to be a bit more layed back. The square contains a kiosk that caters to those who come to enjoy the live music(usually) that plays a variety of different styles.
Lovely area full of bars restaurants and good shopping. Lovely area, lots of old buildings, street cafes, shopping good, lovely old churches to explore, worth a visit
Great shopping district. Possibly one the best shopping area in an European Capital. Chiado is charming, and of course also packed with tourists.
amazing. several differents restaurants, stores, very good for shopping.Some interesting monuments and beautiful churchies

The liveliest part of the town. The shops, the historical cafes, the marvelous restaurants, the "elevadors" to the top, the churches, this is the center of town. Easy and safe to walk around. People are friendly and hospitable.
Please be careful with the slippery sidewalks not safe for some shoes.
Saw 2 motorcycles accidents due to illegal street crossings.

Enjoyable . Lots of people from different corners of the world were there, some taking photos, some simply smoking and drinking, some playing music, some laughing out loud. We sat in a bench near by the road watching the road and how hazardly Portuguese drive the cars in these kind of places where the lanes are hardly visible. You'll see taxi stopping right in the middle of the road to drop in or pick up passengers, horns constantly as there are some late crossers of the road after red signal.Whatever you do, pickup an interest in this place and get yourself entertained.

Great city. We stayed in Chiado for eight nights and it was centrally located to everything in Lisbon.We did day trips to other cities (Sintra, Univ of Coimbra, Evora) within two hours of Lisbon and it was very easy.

Oldest shopping mall in Lisbon. This traditional borough of Lisbon was famous for their fine shops. When part of Chiado was burnt in a fire over 20 years ago, the shopping target shifted to Amoreiras shopping center. The burnt Chiado was rebuild and adapted itself to new interests. It still remains its charm and is an expensive living área.
Lovely downtown area. Lots of great architecture and shops, from the side of the river you can see the bridge and the Christo Rei, this is the real heart of the city!

Cosmopolitan part of the city. This area has everything to charm a tourist. Shops, fado theatres, restaurants, cafes and "Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara". We walked up starting from Baixa and listening fado in "Fado en Chiado" , ended up taking shots from the Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara. It is a must visit in Lisbon.

Nice area of Lisbon to spend time shopping and sightseeing. Chiado is mostly a commercial neighbourhood in Lisbon at Rua Garrett and nearby streets. It is situated between Bairro Alto and Baixa districts. In this area of the city you'll find quite a few international and local retail shops, plenty of restaurants, bars and cafes as well as nice squares and attractions worth seeing. Attractions we enjoyed include the architecturally interesting Elevador de Santa Justa, the ruins of Igreja do Carmo, Museo Nacional de Arte Contemporanea do Chiado, Teatro de Sao Carlos. Interesting squares include Praca Luis de Camoes and the lovely but small Largo do Chiado where you can see delightful calçada portuguesa (mosaic cobblestone pavement). Largo do Carmo, which is just in front of the entrance to Igreja do Carmo and the Archeology Museum, is also a nice square in the Chiado district and good spot for a quite break from sightseeing in the area. You can visit this area by way of the Santa Justa lift from Baixa and Rossio area of the city or by walking up Rua do Carmo to Rua Garrett.

Good to walk around!. This is a very nice neighborhood and I really enjoyed walking around! It has plenty of shopping, restaurants and stuff to do! My hostel was in this neighborhood and it was a great location!
Nice. Lovely places with hundreds of shops selling brands and local stuff. Loads of cafes and restaurants. Lots of local vendors too. lovely to just walk around sit around sipping wine.
Very nice area to explore. Chiado is a nice area to explore and just walk around. It is quite a bit of a shopping scene around but also nice streets and restaurants. Just go and get lost.
Carlsberg Stage was awesome!. The Carlsberg stage was so much fun after the soccer games. Played fun dance music into the night!! Provided a unique fun experience.

Best neighborhood in the town!. The portuguese Soho!
My favorite spot in the world!
Happy, full of colors, flavors, music, smiles.
I could easily live there!

Terrific Sightseeing and Walking Area. You just can't visit Lisbon without spending some time walking around Chiado. Lots of narrow alleys and streets with myriad shops and venues. I highly recommend "Fado in Chiado". We bought our tickets through Viatour. The show was impressive. Meanwhile spend an afternoon or two in Chiado!

Shoppingarea. A fast growing shopping area really develop the last years, and more to come with nice hotels and restaurants, but a warning here a lot of tourist trap places special in the main road but look around and you will find some very nice pearls.
TIPS try restaurants without picture of the food!

A place to go. Downtown with lots of people always full and a place to stay and to enjoy
Lots of cafes and restaurants and fashion shops too
Vibrant. An area with full of people going up and down ,, shops and restaurants around ,, a lively place and nice to spend some times afternoon,,,

Perfect. We arrived in Lisbon that time will be perfect for dinner, settled a bit in our hotel then ask our friendly concierge lady where the best place to eat, then headed to chiado, what a first nite in this city, good food and cheap restaurants around and great for strolling after a hearty dinner, just sit down to one of their Práca and be amazed with beautiful designs of pavements.

Perfect place to stay!. We stayed in Chiado and had everything worth having as a tourist just outside the door! Restaurants, shops and cafes!
Beautiful buildings and the streets with trams going up and down the hill!
Fun & vibrant. A fun & vibrant part of the city. Plenty going on, nice shops. Great rooftop terrace at hotel do Chiado for views & gin. Lots of lovely streets & plaças to explore.

Chiado,on foot. We were passing through during the daytime, heading for the river. The weather was very hot and I confess that I can be a bit single minded when I am 'on a mission'. The area around the square was lovely and we returned later during our holiday.

The part of town to wander!. This central area of Lisbon has lovely shops (Chiado is the name of the square and its surrounding area) - it's definitely a people watching area and to discover some nice eateries. It is of course a popular area for tourists, shopping and immersing oneself in a central part of Lisbon as it it offers a mix of the traditional and more modern Lisbon.

great area. nice shops. good atmosphere. you can have a drink or eating a great pizza at Mezzogiorno. then there is Fnac where you can have shopping. there is as well the famous ccafe' la Brasileira where Pessoa was spending a lot of time
Nice part of the city. Very touristy, old buildings and a lot of shops and cafes. Try going for a walk there after dinner when there is less rush.

World's Oldest Bookstore. Lively area above Rossio, with great Patisseries, interesting shops. Read a tip on Trip Adviser that was helpful - to avoid steep climb, enter Baixa-Chiado subway, take escalator down, walk through the station and take the 4 part escalator up. You'll be in heart of Chiado.
Packed With Tourists and Shoppers. While the Chiado District is pleasant to look at and explore, much of its charm is diminished as I had to contend with a sea of tourists and shoppers.
Nice, lively area of the city, ideal for a stroll!. This is one of the central neighborhoods in Lisbon, it's very lively, has nice squares and plenty of shops.

Great area for strolling, sightseeing. Here you are placed directly into the heart of Lisbon. As in all big cities, wherever tourists are there are many opportunities to get ripped off, figuratively and literally so beware of your surroundings and possessions! Enough said.Then enjoy the old buildings, monuments, statues and the many stores, bars, restaurants in the old part of town. From here you can take a tuk-tuk, or tram or even walk (what a novel idea) to the top of the Castelo. in the big square near the water (Paco) there is a public viewing for the soccer championships right now but otherwise a great area for seeing what is the heart of downtown Lisbon.

Great area, but be aware of pickpockets everywhere. This is a great area, and we were so enjoying it until I was stopped by a kind elderly portugese lady. When in ciities, I always am aware of being extra careful with my handbag. This very kind told me to wear my hand bag across my chest, and hold onto it - I thank her for this - please also be very careful when wandering about - sad advice but truthful.This is the more sophisticated and vibrant part of the city with elegant shopping. including luxurious designer shops, antique and interior design shops, interesting book shops,clubs/bars and restaurants.It has a great very busy central square, with historical buildings on all three sides, a statue of the poet Antonio Ribeiro in the centre, and many great outdoor cafes to sit and people watchApart from this point of the handbag, this area is great,

Typical commercial and retail hub of Lisbon . A nice Pedestrianized street to walk around in the center of Lisbon. Buildings are low rise and pleasant to walk around. About 500-600m long to walk from Commercial square to the obelisk square but relatively pleasant with wide streets . Go to wonder around and go to international brand shops.

The center of activity in Downtown Lisbon. The Chiado district of Lisbon is the center of activity. It is alive with shops, restaurants, outdoor cafes, and night life. It seems that lunch happens after noon and the night life doesn't start until after midnight. You can find all types of dining in Chiado from tappas to casual outdoor dining, to fine dining. It is all in Chiado. One VERY IMPORTANT NOTICE for all those visiting Lisbon, especially the crowded areas is the unbelievable number of PICKPOCKET crimes which are a constant threat to everyone. They are very good so, GUARD YOUR VALUABLES!!!!. ALWAYS assume that you are risk of a pickpocket crime anytime you are in an outdoor area. ALWAYS be AWARE. NEVER let your guard down.
The best place for all your needs. the place is really amazing with all the amazing shopping streets and restaurants you will find everything you need, including a metro station.

Melting pot, meeting point. Amazing for anyone who wants to spend just a day in Lisbon. Cafes, boutiques, shops everything are around this area. Tons of Photography inspirations. Walk in and out of the lanes to check out the place. Lots of currency exchange points here as well. Central to most areas.

Fancy place in Lisbon. Find nice boutiques and restaurants. The vibrant scene of artist, writers and politicians settled here and of course everybody followed...one of the local favorite winemakers opened its tapas place here...check it out

Lively city downtown. We've stayed in this area and location is great as a starting point. Many shops, cafes and restaurants. It really comes to life during night but it is more suitable for younger people. Even though there are more beautiful places in Lisbon you should definitely go for a walk through Chiado.

Fun place. Bustling with life and activities so a good place to wander along day or night with interesting buskers, restaurants and shops...loved the outdoor opera on a street corner with a full orchestra
For the young. Stayed in this area . Really comes to life at night. Not for the faint hearted. At night not suitable for children.

Busy square, lined with commercial shops. This square is impressive due to its size and its funny to see the busyness all day. However, it is lined with commercial tourist shops so not a must-see. The huge fountain/statue is impressive though!

do not forget it. This part of the city is higher than the Baixa (city center) you could arrive by elevator Santa Justa (made by Eiffel), tram (very nice) or sidewalking. In Chiado there is a nice square (Camoens), nice palce to see the whole city, resturantes, pubs, pastelarias,...
Great window shopping . Great window shopping. Would be a great place to stay in a hotel. Nice place for people watching. Near to the Metro when tired of walking.

Interesting Day and Night. Chiado offers plenty of shopping and eating during the day along with churches, San Justa Lift and other monuments to visit.
During the night, it is very lively with bars and restaurants.

Not a dull moment. Something for everyone from trend setters to shopaholics to party animals. Hard to believe that most of the building have been around for ages. The atmosphere is amazing with good food and lots to see and do

More of the Same. Here's the problem: with the Brand takeover of every major and minor city, it's getting to the point where there is no there, there. We found the main area of Chiado no different (with the exception of a lot of hill-climbing) than any other city pretty much everywhere in the world. Same brands, same offerings. Who cares?I am hoping that at some point, cities will stop letting corporate brands consume all the available space, and create some kind of retail rent structure that allows local businesses to survive and thrive. Otherwise, what's the point in visiting these places anymore?

Lisbon Chic. This is the place to walk around with all the locals. Lisbon style. Masses of restaurants , coffee shops and the new Young Lisbon society. Terrific in Winter outstanding in Summer. Loads of really good buskers and a very special atmosphere. Really want to be there now! Relaxed in Lisbon sort of way.

Nice place to take a coffee and listen music bands. Nice place that you should cross if you want to visit Bairro Alto. There is a lot of restaurants and coffee shops where you can seat for a while and enjoy the atmosphere.
Walk around and chill. Great place to hang out or start a walking tour and very affordable and authentic bars in the neighborhood.
Fun area to explore. wander through and enjoy the whole part! This is where the plenty of interesting shops stand. Very nice architecture too,,
Perfect for shopping. drinks and a leisurely evening walk. Dont miss the Chiado for a feel of the city buzz. Lovely shops to visit and plenty of lisbon charm. this is a quintessential experience
Nice place. Nice area suitable for walking. There are many shops and restaurants, and crowds of people. When you're here, go up the elevador .

Great neighbourhood. As a tourist we like to walk around and we really liked this neigbourhood. The architecture is amazing, love the Palacio Chiado for dinner. And I actually felt like a resident, so nice!

another popular neighbourhood in Lisbon. next to Alfama, the most popular tourist place. when I take friends to see Lisbon for the first time, I always start in Chiado.... it is an experience on its own...
Cool tile patttern. There is a really cool tile pattern on the square. The fountains are nice to see/photograph and there are some nice shops surrounding the square. Nice to see while in Lisbon.
Nice lightshow. A very nice and long light show in the middle of the city. A place to go in the evening before dinner!

Nice place to go for a good walking. A very nice place to see, take pictures and history from Portugal, very close to other attractions. Very nice to go for a good walking to find all the mysteries of Lisbon.

Boutique are of Lisbon. Chiado is just set off from the central area of Baxia and offers a number of excellent Cafes & Shops as well as pleasant walks through the narrow streets & buildings, well worth a visit

One of our favorite area in Lisbon. We loved this area. It has many small shops, restaurants and nightlife. The prices are a bit more competitive and lower than the Lisbon downtown center. The crowd is a bit younger (20 - 50) and in my opinion; safe.
The centre of Lisbon. Chiado is the modern part of Lisbon and here you can find all kinds of shops and go for your life. Great place to be.
Heart of Old Lisbon. This area is full of stores and restaurants and very near the Commercial Plaza and Apolina cruise piers. Watch for the traffic.
Lively friendly area. Nice area with god access to the city centre, the water front and tram 28. Lots of restaurants and bars and good shops

Great shopping! . We started at Barrio Alto and walked down to Chiado turn which is better than walking up. Chiado had this square where we saw some street performers and visited this amazing old church. Just beautiful. You can find some nice shops that are reasonable. And the outdoor restaurants look pretty good and there are a bunch of street singers and performers. We had a nice few hours there.

Pretty good shopping experience. Chiado is the main shopping area in Lisbon. It's a beautiful walk with lots of small and large chain shops to spent your hard earned euros. My biggest complaint is no matter where I looked, I couldn't find a Ronoldo jersey. Not the fault of the Chiado shopping district, but still annoying.The route to Chiado from my hotel (the Ritz Four Seasons) is lined with high end stores, where as Chiado is more regular stores and small shops. You can easily end your shopping trip with a stroll down the boardwalk and stop for a drink or lunch along the water. If you're with the right company, you might even call it magical.

Upmarket area of central Lisbon. Lovely area of Lisbon but a little more upmarket than Alfama and Bairro Alto (although it borders the latter). You can experience A brasileira café in Rua Garrett or the trendy fashion shops like Ana Salazar (probably Portugal's most notorious designer). Everything in this neighbourhood oozes sophistication.

Nice for a summertime stroll. We live in the Lisbon area, and we come here once in a while for no particular reason. Pleasant walk with a lively atmosphere when the weather is nice. Once you reach the top (assuming you started at the bottom, in Restauradoes or Rossio), where you are not far from Bairro Alto, you can sit down for a cold beer, do some people watching, and just enjoy the environment.
Again a great place to take a walk. A great place to take a walk around Lisbon and experience life in Lisbon. Lisbon has great squares to experience both during the day and at night.

The In place to be. I'd rate this area as the number one place to be. Restaurants all over as well as numerous cafe's. Street performers on every Praca. Easy access to the Metro. The area has a pulse and is easy to walk, though Lisbon does have hills. This is a not to miss area.
Favourite spot. Loved the area, nice people, nice places to go, lively and buzzing. The only downside were the sellers on the street but you get used to it.

Nice shopping street. Lovely area with clothes shops, book shops and coffee shops. The area had a nice feel about it. Apparently it has the oldest book shop in the world? Great for a daytime stroll and people watching.

Great buzzy area. One of the many squares in Lisbon, lots of lovely buildings, places to eat and drink. Public transport available, took tug's, trams if you don't fancy walking the many hills in Lisbon!

A day time visit. Down a very steep hill from the shopping area I recommend you take a tuck tuck or tram back up.
Lisbon is the city of 7 hills but there are many more than that in reality

Very noisy and bustling . We stayed in the area for a weekend during our trip around Portugal. The area is very alive, with many restaurants, bars, museums and shops. At night the city exploded into a drinking haven so I would caution any older couples or those looking for a peaceful break when considering staying here. We don't mind the noise (helped by our almost soundproof windows).

Terrific area for window shopping and cafes. The Chiado is a terrific area to shop in. There are bookstores, shoe stores, clothing stores, ceramics, wine, cafes and restaurants and ice cream. There is something for everyone in the Chiado.

Very interesting shopping area crammed with eateries and old architecture. I spent several hours just wandering and window-shopping. You will find the usual mall retailers among the local "nice" shops. If you tire or get thirsty you won't have far to walk before you find a good spot in which to recuperate.

Stunning square in the city, but full of drug pushers, lots of begging and selling!. Deteriorated one of the parts of the centre here over the last years. Poorly policed, lots of drugs, selling, and begging. You have to be firm and either ignore or say a firm "NO". It spoils the city now.
Wonderful central square. This is where the city of Lisbon meets. Everyone throngs around, trams rattle by, the architecture is imposing, the space wide and welcoming. Wander through and enjoy.
Great to explore. This is a fun area of Lisbon to explore. Plenty of nice and interesting shops. Many good restaurants and cafes. Wonderful mix of architecture, too.
Very nice area for shopping. and one of the most beautiful parts of Lisbon with nice shops, reastaurants and cafes - we loved it.

Upscale tourism. Enjoyable walk around. We stayed in a comfortable apartment in Baixa district where the area is interesting but run down. It's nice to get out and about in the better maintained Chiado .
Lively And Busy Chiado. So much to see and so much to do in Chiado. Super entertaining place to be in, day or night. Lots of action.
Great district to discover on a stroll.. Historic area with nice shops, parks, street cafés, street music bands, beautiful landmarks, very vibrant area!

A great place to chill out and people watch. We walked down through Barrio Alto to Chiado and enjoyed the narrow streets and the pavement cafes. Grab a table and a small, cold beer and watch the world go by. At night it buzzes and there are numerous options for dinner or a light meal - we found street entertainers and numerous small shops to browse through.

Nice area for a stroll and a coffee. Lots of streets and squares to explore... Just go on foot and follow your nose. It's a bit hilly but you'll see nice little gems almost everywhere: tiny shops, nice cafes, good coffee, friendly people
Where every tourist in Lisbon goes.. Great area, great atmosphere. Lots of people but relaxed. Shops for all pockets and tastes. Lots of street cafes.

Fascinating. It is a very nice area in Lisbon. I preferred it to Bairro Alto and Alfama, which are usually the districts people advise to visit. I didn't find a particular atmosphere there, while I enjoyed Chiado. It is fascinating and intriguing, and it has nice things to see around it, like the Carmo Church. If you are in Lisbon, I'd advise to visit the area and its Churches.
Atmosphere!. Just image that you are at a place which is like 200 years ago and in the very present at the same time.
Excellent shopping and restaurants. And it's not as steep as you think once you get going. Very good range and all reasonably priced just as is everything in Portugal.

A historic area in which to walk and explore. A historic area, where the streets in one direction are quite logical, but in the other (going up the hill) can be a little confusing. A mixture of shops, bars, cafes and many churches rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake, all of which are worth visiting.

Shops n walks. Within your plans for this vibrant city which gives many moods, there will be day for window shopping, chatting on coffee and buying gifts. For that day you can go to Chiado area. Well there is no particular sign that which mark the area but these are number of parallel streets squared by Rossio and Barrio alto area, view to river and Alfama. You can eat best food on outdoor sitting restaurants, buy local home decor items made of cork, buy from your international designers outlets and enjoy local confectionery.It is also great spot for travel photography. All yours...

My favourite part of town. Our hostel was in this part of town and we loved the area! There are a great many wonderful bakeries and Restaurants as well as loads of Shops in Chiado which more than makes up for having to trudge up Lisbons hills mostly all the time.
A hilly walk, but many shops. This was a great area for shopping and walking around, but make sure to wear comfortable shoes - the streets require it!
Pretty part of Lisbon . All of these places you sort of wonder in and out of and the neighbourhoods I didn't feel were that distinct from each other. Beware the hills in the mid day sun.
Great for shops.. A lovely and lively area to explore. Lots of good restaurants, cafes and great interesting shops. It is a bit hilly, but worth it.

Nice area for a walk. Although we did not stay in this area we heard so much of Chiado that your trip will never be complete if you do not walk around Chiado neighbourhood. We had a pleasant walk which was dotted with many little restaurants, cafes, antiquity shops and retail outlets. Very pleasant area to stroll. The best restaurant that you should try here is called Sea Me. Reserve earlier as it is always fully booked. Enjoy Chiado.

Lively and entertaining. This is a must visit on a sunny day in Lisbon. The very talented street musicians rotate in and out, creating a party-like atmosphere. Enjoy a bica (espresso) at an outdoor table, listen to the music - and don't forget to tip the musicians - and enjoy the scenery in the company of a life-sized statue of noted Portuguese poet Pessoa. Oh, and the shopping isn't bad, either.
Shopping and Dining . Chic downtown Lisbon good for walkers, dining and shopping. Busy and vibrant. There are lots of tourist and shoppers. The restaurants are more expensive but is a charming area.

see it before other fire destroys the place. Traditional area where intellectuals and pretence intellectuals spend their time, even today (lol). Nothing better to exercise your hearth climbing from Rossio do Chiado, have a seat at the most traditional coffee shop of Lisbon "A Brasileira" in company of the late poet Fernando Pessoa (well his statue). In the night of 25/26 April 1974 the Marines, from the North and the 2nd of Cavalry form South sieged the political police holding the responsible for any political prisoner they could kill. Besides that you can either go West down to the Parliament in Sao Bento or climb North and enjoy new perspectives of Lisbon.Of course I go there a lot and I know Lisbon so don't care with the dates I put here.
Nice shopping area . Nice shopping area with cosy cafes and restaurants. Here and there Portugese designers but mainly the shops for everybody budget.

Just One Of The Many 'Must Do's' in Lisbon. Lisbon - being such a vibrant cosmopolitan city in Portugal, there is much to do and much to see and so a visit and 'walk about' in the 'Chiado' area of the city is an absolute 'Must Do' for visitors time and again. You can walk the area time and again and never bore from the atmosphere day or night, rain or shine. Browse the stores, stop for a snack or a meal or just a glass of Vino Tinto, just try it once, you will be enchanted.
Great nightlife and restaurants!. Great area of Lisbon for nightlife and wide variety of restaurants in and around the little streets. Metro stops right there, couldn't be easier!

Great place for eating and shopping. A very nice area in Lisbon to walk around, they have many shops and places to eat or have a tea or coffee. There is also an indoor shopping centre (incase it gets rainy), some areas are tough to manage if you have a stroller or wheelchair with you.

Nice place. Chiado is one of the places to go if you are visiting Lisbon. Recently rehabilitated (due to a huge fire), it’s full of life, stores and culture. Counts with Lisbon’s most famous café: A Brasileira. Where you’ll find, immortalized, one of their best writers: Fernando Pessoa. Rua Garrett has oldest bookshop of the World (1732) which is worth a look. Chiado is technically part of the Bairro Alto, but it has developed an atmosphere and quality of its own and in the past was regarded as the literary and intellectual melting pot of Lisbon. Largo do Chiado is a pleasant square with a variety of restaurants and cafes.
beautiful chic downtown lisbon. Nice place for walkers, have a bite or even a fancy drink. Perfect atmosphere for mostly everything. Also, good for shopping.
quaint. charming area to walk around in. There is also an historic elevator one can ride up (for a fee) to get a view, but it cannot rank with the castle.
Interesting area. Bust location with lots of eateries & shopping.Best seen in the early afternoon as it is less busy.
Quality area. Chiado is nice city centre area. Best to keep to Rua do Garrett & area to north of it. Catch tram 28 here at terminus to get seat. Some great shops & on-street cafe seating.

Center of it all. Cool boutique restaurants, always get the fresh orange juice, always. Pretty little shops. Don't be afraid to ask questions to the locals. They will lead you to Thier favorite spots. You'll see street performers and art students. Embrace it all. Wear comfortable shoes. Lots of hills

One of my favorite neighborhoods in Lisbon . Yes there are a lot of tourists and shoppers, yes the restaurants are a little more expensive but there is some real charm to this area that you don't get in other parts of Lisbon. It's safe, comfortable, filled with beautiful views and most of all awesome coffee bars! Stand with the locals and have a morning espresso!
City Walk Around of Lisbon. This is an interesting area where one can walk comfortably, visit shops and even dine in cozy nice restos.

Vibrant. This is a busy, bustling are to the west of Rossio. Full of shops, cafes and restaurants. Plenty of activity here, both day and night, and it is good to just wander around. A little run down - a coat of paint would not go amiss, but the shabbiness does add to the charm.

This place is a must. Whether during the day or at night this place is the central place in Lisbon. Enjoy a beer on one of the sidewalks, or just relax and watch the busy life of Lisbon pass by. Most tourists, but also locals in this bustling city.
Busy bustling area of the city. Love it. Easy walking albeit with hills. Great restaurants and shops. Lively at night until well into the early morning
Lovely trendy Lisbon. Chiado is full of trendy shops, coffee shops, bars and restaurants. Very lively and colourful. An absolute must for Lisbon!
Beautiful Area. Spent a couple hours in the surrounding area especially where the water comes up, absolutely awesome place to just spend some time with family and take in the view!
Interesting spots to see. Our favorite places to see were the miradouro (overlook spot), the Igreja do Carmo (ruined church) and walking the streets of this area.
Quaint part of the city, that has become emblematic of Llisbon for me.. Quaint part of the city, that has become emblematic of Llisbon for me. Some great restraints and shopping. Well worth a trip.
Good to walk around in a relaxing afternoon.... Good for shopping and food. It's easy to walk around and many nice squares are steps away. And the famous cable car is not far away.

Feel the original blend of Lisbonnians!. One of the centres of the hustle of the old city. Used to be the focus of all the literary disputes and the last cri de la mode de Paris. Today it's the place where you'll find anyone that visit Lisbon. Depart point to the night spots.

Great Shopping. Lovely area of Lisbon to mooch around shopping/eating and enjoying the city from a higher level.
Great food available from standard junk food to traditional Portugese foods.

like the crowdy and cosy place, you got it. Look around between the different shops, restaurants, bars and terraces, enjoy a glass of wine or champagne with some famous pastry called "pasteis".
Look to the crowd, from youngsters up to older couples enjoying the view and the atmosphere.
Look into the small alleys, you'll be amazed what you find.

Trendy Barrio. Chiado is one of those places with a bit of everything. Beautiful wide pedestrianised areas paved with the iconic Portuguese stonework, compact sunny squares and frenetic areas of road where cars jostle with Tuk Tuks and old-fashioned 'dumpy' trams for the limited space. There are chain stores, large independents and small mom and pop shops selling whatever you think you need across a huge price range and there are some unusual offerings of quality local, and unusual, products in some delightful old premises. Plenty of places to eat and drink ranging from the pricier avenue seatings to the small back street restaurants. You need comfortable shoes and stout legs for your time in this neighbourhood as it is very hilly. Well worth the effort to get up to whilst holidaying in Lisbon.

Lovely area. We stayed in the hotel Chiada, which although pricey was very comfortable, nice big room, great breakfast, including gluten free toast for me. Although an extremely busy, central area, there was no night noise. Lovely central place to stay.

Biaxa Chiado. Chiado us a trendy area with a lot of shops, some restaurants and bars. It is a very busy hive of activity in the later day and evening. It is mostly a shopping area with trendy shops and many young people.
Exciting. A very active, beautiful neighborhood. Plenty of diverse shopping choices. All filled with elegant selections.

This is a happening place. To get here, let me warn you means climbing one heck of a hill, or....going to the Baixa-Chaido metro station and riding the free escalators. Saves 180 stair steps. There is the Baixa exit/entrance and the Largo Chiado exit/entrance. Big difference.A beautiful Belle Epoque coffee house is at the mouth of the metro. Catch the Tram #28 at the square if you like. The square is not square. But rather an upper square and and a trapezoid metro entrance section. Streets streaming out from the metro are all worth walking. Lovely streets.
Trendy. Lots of great restaurants, cafés and upscale shops. We stayed in the Baixa area but spent a lot of time here. Cafe Brasileiro is a must with live entertainment in the plaza.

Good walk around in the cool months. Reached at the end of a 5km walk from our hotel. The March air was cool with temperatures of 14-16 C. A huge square with history attached to it. Cross the road & on the seafront. Lovely atmosphere & ambience. Worth a visit definitely

Great place to wander with friends. Spent a week in Lisbon for work and at end of day was able to head down to Chiado area. Was with a group of colleagues and it was fun popping in and out of shops and trying different things to eat. At night down by the water, everything is lit up with lots of people wandering around. Grab a coffee and walk or sit at one of the many street cafes and enjoy people watching. Must see place if you are in Lisbon!

Very central easy to get there great place. Went there several times. Very easy to get there and lots to do and see. Great shops. Bought nice shoes. Great choice of restaurants and cocktail bars or coffee shops. Excellent street entertainment ar Chiado largo.

You will need more than a day, in this district. Chiado is located between the bustling neighbourhoods of Bairro Alto and Baixa Pombalina.It is also the name of the square and its surrounding area which is full of designer boutiques, restaurants, bookstores and famous cafes.It doesn’t stop here, as there is a plethora of Baroque style churches and many other famous monuments to see within this area.A great area to visit, both during the day and night.
Hilly hilly hilly. Be ready to walk them hills!!! A beautiful neighborhood with many scenic moments but lots and lots of hills!
just downtown. It's a downtown of old city. Monuments, shops etc. Many people. Very noizy area. Nice view to the river. Beware of pickpockets.
Fine area. Chiado always have been the "IN" Lisbon district, fine shops, restaurants, coffee shops and historical places.

Photographers dream. Great hilly suburb of Lisbon that leads to some great secrets hidden away, which you can only find on foot. Portuguese in every sense of the word. Beautiful buildings, tiled facades and daily life hustles and bustles about the area. If you're a photographer looking some magic, the magic is here. Every moment is time stoppingly beautiful in every sense of the word - from old ladies calling out to each other across the streets to the men socialising out the front of local shops. If you want a small taste of lisbon life spend the day wandering all the backstreets - just have your legs prepared!

Must see area of Lisbon. As well as Belem and the castle, Chiada is the other must-see area of Lisbon to visit. Be aware though that some parts are quite hilly. All worthwhile though and the Portuguese people are wonderful.

The place to go!. An absolute must if you're visiting Lisbon - such a great selection of shops and restaurants in a beautifully relaxed setting. A wonderful place to relax and people watch in the city.
Unforgettable!!!. You must to hang out on the streets, calmly, taking the time to enjoy the shops, the coffe shops and museums. Don't forget the great viewpoints!!!

A vibrant district. Everywhere you walk in any of those streets, there is something to see. The variety of shopping options , the architecture of the houses and the many little parks on the way are surprising. Excellent restaurants and cafés. Great views on streets going up the hill on overlooking at tge city. A must see of Lisbon.

The place to be. Chiado is definitely the place to be..shopping...lots of streets with lots of reasonable restaurants. .the water front is at the end where the statue is if you just want to hang out by the water... it's a lovely and lively place to be.. lots of mimes and street performers.Did lots of shopping . Dining and hanging out in this location.Can't say enough how I love this area.. really a definite must go.
really nice. great place. lots of nice buildings. Lots of nice places to eat. Nice squares and nice view over the river

Beautiful section of the city worth checking out --- and its flat!. This is always a nice area to walk around in especially in cooler months - in the summer the wind seems to forget to come blowing through here. Do be careful that with the long straight streets cars sometimes come zooming through. The tourists mainly stick to the pedestrian streets and that is where more of the restaurants and shops are anyway.

MAGICAL PLACE. Chiado it is and always be, one of the most MAGICAL places to visit in Lisbon! Don't miss it! It's absolutely FABULOUS, CHARMING, GLAMOROUS.... a "must see" place to be! To go and explore as much as one can! I do it often! Trust me! I simply ADORE it!
Fantastic. We had to use this square a lot to get through Lisbon and we loved it. It has lots of restaurants nearby and is so beautiful. Definitely a lovely square to visit!

A Sentimental Journey. In upper downtown Lisbon this area is 'The One' - full of old charm and seduction with its antique, well preserved façades ! You can´t miss it - it's a must see !In a few minutes you'll feel at the heart of 'Bairro Alto' - the highest quarter of Lisbon with typical Fado restaurants and 'tascas' and 'the' beerhouse - 'A Trindade'. Give it a try and you'll feel amazed at its huge and beautiful decorative tiles inside: it was once a convent . . .A few old churches, boutique hotels and commerce in general will complete the picture !The Opera House - Teatro Nacional de S. Carlos - is a few steps away and in summer during one month there's always an open air show going on . . .Just let yourself GO !
Chiado is THE place to visit downtown Lisbon!. It's the most trendy neighbourhood in Lisbon. Gorgeous views on rooftop cafés overlooking the Tagus river and S. Jorge's Castle.
Great walk and stores!. Nice to walk. Hard and expansível to Park. Great and traditional shopping. Dont forget to visit the mítical Brasileira.
One of the must see in Lisbon. Chiado is one of the places you must go while in Lisbon...great architecture, great restaurants , shops and so on

Amazing sights around every corner. Castles, cathedrals, statues, fountains, plazas.... Around every corner and passing every street the view of the surrounding hillside and the architecture is spectacular. Spent all morning walking around the streets here all the way down to placa de comercio.

Lovely place to look around!. Lovely square with good history. Plenty of shopping options, but you will end up burning a hole in your pocket because all are top end brands.If you don't mind spending the extra buck, this is the place for you!

shopping with individuality!. pretty cobbled streets, some main chains that you might find anywhere in Europe, but also if you look, individual shops like the lovely glove shop at 87a do carmo - if you are ever going to buy gloves, do it here. all colours of the rainbow, soft leather, and perfectly fitting. also good jewelry including the Portuguese gilded filigree. I visited in February when it was quiet, without the rush of tourists you might expect to see in the summer. it was regularly rainy, but it never lasted more than 10 minutes then the sun came out, and as long as you were walking it didn't get too cold!
Great shopping . Love this area for a wander round the shops, nice cafes and a spot of people watching. New Honorato Hamburgers in the area is great.
Cute. Cute area with nice shops and a good nightlife. Visiting the oldest bookstore in the world is a must, as well as Cafe Brasilia (you can just imagine Pessoa sipping absinthe inside!)

Great for typical eats and people watching. Kind of the tourism heart of Lisbon. You can wander for hours. Lots of pigeons, fountains, status, monuments, cafes, shops, performers. Great for street photography.

Lovely to walk around. Another lovely place to stroll and absorb more of Lisbon.
Lovely sandwich shop in the square. Probably not more than an hour or so.
High street shopping area. High street shopping area. Beautiful pedestrian floor with tiles. Taking pictures of the old trams going back and forth is fun.
Lisbon. I love everything about Lisbon. This is another beautiful part of the beautiful city. Explore as much as you can.

Great to walk around!. Filled with shops and restaurants, this area is perfect for shopping and eating. Filled with locals and tourists it is always busy. It is also a prime area for pick pockets and beggars. Don't let that deter you from visiting, as with any city you need to be alert.
Great neighbourhood. Nice place to have a tipical meal, walk through the narrow streets with amazing hostels and tapas restaurants.

The Streets of Lisbon. I am totally in love with Portugal. I just love the city, the streets and the Chiado is a perfect example of how history has managed to be kept intact with the modern times. That is the beauty of Europe as a whole... The architecture is a constant reminder of the rich heritage and culture for the world to enjoy. I just loved walking in the area filled with small shops, cafes, retail stores and did I say great food.
Ortsteil von lissabon, sehr geil. hier findet ihr alles, strassenmusiker, shopping, up and down.nice eating.grandios.the elevator also staying here

Pick pocket be carful . Be carful of pick pockets. Witnessed a family that was almost pick pocketed. The family realized that they were being pick pocketed and ran away. Astonishingly, the pick pocketers chased after them. Pick pocketers disguised themselves as tourists.

Best location if you want to tour Lisbon and be able to walk everywhere. We rented a beautiful penthouse apartmetn in CHiado adjacent to the CHiado Shopping Center and could not have been mroe pleased with our choice. We walked everywhere. If you head west from Baixa, you'll enter this shopping district which is probably the most centrally located district in Lisbon.. From its perch on a hill, it's traversed by Rua Garrett (where our apartment was located), named for the noted romantic writer João Batista de Almeida Garrett (1799-1854). Many of the finest shops in the city, such as the Vista Alegre, a china and porcelain house, are here. One coffeehouse in particular, A Brasileira, has been a traditional gathering spot for the Portuguese literati. The food was nto great but the place is worth visiting. It is beautiful (see photos).at night is is one of the nciest neighborhoods to walk through. There is also a famous Santini Ice Cream shop right next tot he Chiado shopping Center. See the neighborhood photos. If you can rent an apartment or find a hotel in Chiado, I would stay there for sure.
top top top. must go!!dont miss it!!...one of the best places to go in Lisbon. nice restaurants and cafés. just go

Nice comfortable walk. Chiado has many nice shops (yes, all the global brands as well, but many unique ones) and beautiful mosaics on the sidewalks. Just looking at those mosaics are interesting (they do personalized for the shops as well), but you have many small squares and lively cafe/restaurants to have a good rest to do the people watching. Largo do Carmo is my favorite seeing a guard at work next to the Carmo Convent. Near Trinidad theatre, don't miss a beautiful building with amazing tile works.

Chiado - the happening Street !. If you wanna walk on a street that has performers, some great shopping stores, music playing and so much more, visit the Chiado - it is a street with a Buzz, and keeps you going for a while. Loved it !
Beautiful. It’s a nice and very interesting historical part of city, however be aware of pickpocket and drug dealers who offers their fake drugs right in the centers of the streets and squares

Interesting . We only spent a brief time in the large open square on our way through to somewhere else , plenty of high end retail shops and a few points of interest.. Worth a visit if passing through
Old charming neighborhood. Chiado is a charming neighborhood, with shops, cafes, nice place to walk around. It is centrally located, and is very nice for an afternoon stroll.

The trendiest "barrio" in town. Nice during the day and at night, this barrio is by far the trendiest in town. High street shops and high class hotels and restaurants are located in this neighbourhood. It is also the setting of many scenes of the Portuguese soap opera "Laços de sangue".

Charming. Nice authentic neighborhood to wander around, small streets, local shops and restaurants. Day time for a coffee and pastry or in the evening when you can have a nice meal and hear the fado music.
Much overrated, noisy and polluted. Not much to add to the title. Hords of tourists. Let's hope they won't invade some other more pleasant parts of the city.

The heart bit of the city - any hour. Chiado is for me the heart of the city. there you can have good resturants, shops, cafes. You can just stay in a cafe, sitting, and watching people in the street. You have churches, museums, life!
Stroll.. Very nice place for photo opportunity, little socializing supported by smart food establishments and plenty of shopping action (well stocked Massimo Dutti).

Heartbeat of the City. The Old Town of Lisbon is the true heart of the city. It is from here where Lisbon was seeded and blossomed bringing forward its rich history. Today the area is a collection of shops, cafes, street entertainers, clubs, etc. while bathed in colorful buildings and artistic graffiti. Add to this the opportunity to people watch and you have a great place to spend time and enjoy life.

The heart of the city. You can be there by tram, metro, or taxi, if you want shopping, food, a drink or even just a walk, this place is just perfect, it would never let you down, you didn't see Lisbon if you didn't walk here.

Chiado. A place that you have to visit. One of the most emblematic places of Lisbon. Ttem several shops, a good atmosphere and plenty of lighting that makes it enjoyable and appealing visiting the city of Lisbon. I strongly recommend

A must-see bustle of restaurants, shops, hot chestnuts,. A must-see bustle of bars,restaurants, shops, hot chestnuts,coffee shops and friendly people. Get your tour bus tickets here, but check out the different timetables,some are hourly and can involve long waits in inclement weather.

Impossible to miss. The "baixa" is impossible to miss, since it is probably destination #1 for all tourists in Lisbon. Be sure not to miss the "Armazens do Chiado" - it was rebuilt after a big fire hit that part of town. It is a very "lisboeta - alfacinha" place and you can use it as a free way of getting up to the "bairro alto" by elevator.
Nice for nightlife and foodies. Nice quirky bars and pubs, lots of places to eat. Lots of clubs in the area. Can be very busy after 9pm.
Nothing to rave about. Chiado area was ok, but generally not over impressed. A few small nice shops. Worth seeing for yourself really as everyone is different!!
Beautifull Shopping Area. With several stores, coffees and restaurants is one of the most crowded areas of Lisbon. Great ambience, people walking on the street, just perfect for a sunday afternoon!

Perfect place to stay. We stayed in the Chiado neighborhood for 4 nights in December. It was the perfect place to stay and get around. We loved all of the bakeries and restaurants nearby and enjoyed wandering up and down the steep streets, getting perfectly lost in Lisbon. I would go back and stay in this neighborhood again.
Old town. This area is amazing with the tram going up very narrow streets with restaurants and attractions easy to visit
nice authentic neighbourhood. nice authentic neighborhood: small streets, local sops and restaurants. nice or a walk in the evening when you can small the food and hear the fado music
Maravilhosas férias . I have been at Chiado before but this opportunity I enjoy it much more . It is a wonderful area , there are many good restaurants such as Cantinho do Avilez
nice place. Pretty and well kept part of Lisbon. Lot of restaurants, museums, stores. Great view to the river, in winter - an ice skate ring.

Ranked best by well traveled visitors.. We are family of 5, of which 3 are teens (13 - 16 yrs.). We stayed on Avda. Libertad and enjoyed the proximity to great restaurants in short walking distance on Rua De Santo Antao. The walk down Rua Augusta was filled with great shops , street performers, and a vibrant festive crowd. We have been to Rome, Madrid, Riviera Maya in recent years yet we found Lisbon a hidden gem for a great vacation.We hope others take the time to discover this wonderful city that offers great food, amazing history, and fabulous hospitality.

Great area with lots of squares and history packed in it! Tram 28 passes most of its streets!. Make sure to do the free walking tour of Baixa-chiado if you're in the area! It'll give you a whole different feel of the place :)
Nice to explore. Pretty chic and hip neighborhood in Lisbon. A lot of nice restaurants. Wear comfortable shoes, you'll do a lot of walking.

Historical and Trendy. Chiado is a trendy historical area of Lisbon! Plenty of branded stores some are high end (Hermes for example) and nice restaurants. Three theaters in this area (Trindade, São Carlos and São Luiz). The perfect spot for shopping outside and for a walk. For teenagers it's also near Bairro Alto - a starting point for all-night-long fun!

Busy downtown Lisbon. This area is the heart of Lisbon and is probably a mandatory part of any visit. Plenty of interesting old buildings to admire and of course many shops along the streets. A few impressive squares to check out nad of course the archway on Rua Augusta. Easy to walk around and generally soak up the atmosphere. Personally I found some of the less busy areas to be more interesting (with their narrow streets etc) than here, but it's still worth a look.

Great area for walking. Lots of interesting architectural buildings. Plenty of fabulous restaurants and bars. Don't forget the Fado - interesting to listen.Great area to walk at night especially at weekends, vibrant with plenty of interesting people.

watch out. nice square, central and easy to access. there are some shops and restaurants near by. it looked safe but every time that I visited I was approached by a couple of individuals selling cocaine

The rebirth of a neighborhood. Between Bairro Alto and Down Town, this neighborhood was, in the nineteenth century, very " chic". You could see one the most famous Portuguese writers - Eça de Queiroz - strolling with his top hat, cane and monocle, along with other Portuguese intellectuals.They had a chat in "Brasileira cafe" - still exists - and, then, walking to Rua Nova do Almada, or going up to " Príncipe Real"Fernando Pessoa - one of the mightiest Portuguese poets - loved to go there and you can see him sitting at a table ( sculpture of Lagoa Henriques).Then, in 1988, a large fire broke out and great part of commerce disappeared.Painstakingly it was rebuilt according to Sisa Vieira ( the Portuguese world known architect) project.Now, Chiado is vibrant with life and commerce.Modern shopping centers following the ancient architectural line, beautiful baroque churches, the Nationa Opera House ( São Carlos), the ancient " Teatro da Trindade", shops and street artists will make your visit worth wile.
Shops. Mostly pedestrian area with lots of shops. Also contains elevator which leads to archeological museum.

Lisbon - one day. I live near Lisbon. When I have a free day I go to Chiado. It's the place I recommend if you only have one day to visit the city.You have stores, restaurants, monuments, and movement. People going to school, to business, to date, to play music...Near Chiado you have the train station (Eifel), the Elevador de Santa Justa, Rua Augusta and Terreiro do Paço.If you're interested in the 1755's earthquake, you'll find ruins there.From Chiado, you can see the river and, if you want to stay for the night, you can go to Bica or Bairro Alto.

Nice part of town. When in Lisbon you need to check out this area! It's full of stores, cafés, restaurants and squares. It's a nice place to explore by foot. Vibrant during the day & safe during evenings. Easy access to other older parts of the city as well.
Great place for a day out. You will invariably be in chiafo if you visit lisbon. You can hang out the whole day and enjoy shopping, cafes and fado bar
Busy square. A busy place to walk around and sit to people watch. We sat and had lunch watching a huge liner coming in. Good place to pick the trams too.
Awesome. Fun experience with a lot of shops eateries etc here. Was lit up beautifully owing to Christmas. Overall worth the time spent!

The best place to shop in typical Lisbon! . I love Baixa Chiado! It gives you a ''smell'' of old style Lisboa! The stores are cute, the cafes are a Must, and the restaurants are delicious. Of you travel to Lisbon, don't miss it!

Can't miss it. If you are wondering around Lisbon streets and areas, it's impossible to miss Chiado. It's a very central point from where you can head up to other areas. Very close to Bairro Alto, Rossio and many others. Lots of tourists on the street and very energetic and noisy in a positive way. Beautiful crowds!
I love it!. Love the chiado! It's my favorite part of town. There's a lot of trendy cafes and shops. A perfect combination between old and new places!
Chiado. Chiado, Alfama and Belem are musts to see in Lisbon. Chiado is easy to get, has a lot of places to shop and stalls with alcohol and entertainment

A place to shop.... After going to Bairo Alto we decided to walk thru the streets going to chiado..this is the place where you can do some of your shoppings.Although the place is crowded but you'll surely enjoy doing your purchases.
Atmospheric. We walked through Chiado almost everyday. The buskers Provided a great diversity of music and the street artists were very entertaining. Lovely area.
Must to see when in Lisbon . Food, sites, shopping, all in one area. Must for any tourist. It's on the hop on hop off bus tour. Chiado, alfama, bairro alto, and Belém are a must.

Lovely place for an evening. Don't miss the Chiado! What a great place to have a wine, enjoy good music, see beautiful people and chill around! Even during the day is a great place, but you have to check it during the night!!!

Lively area. Lively place...nice to just sit by the river with a couple of beers and catch up on some conversation. ..you do have a few buskers playing some familiar tunes in the background. ..that might bring back some memories :)
Perfect. We stayed here and it must be one of the best areas to stay in as it is close to everything, bars, shop,s restaurants, transport, everything. Loved it would certainly stay in this area again

It's Lisbon. Chiado is at the heart of Lisbon. It has become a bit too touristic and busy, and it is unlikely that you will experience much of an authentic local vibe there. But it is beautiful and one can't go to Lisbon and miss Chiado.

Great area. What a great area to just hang out. Later we found out that the whole thing was built many years ago on stilts after the terrible earthquake. They arent sure, but the 19th? century or older technology they thing also adds stability prevention against future earthquakes. My wife and I ate in the are, took pictures and enjoyed the cool breeze coming off the water. You could easily spend a day or more just in this area.

Favorite Place. As a Portuguese away from home, every time I go to Lisbon, I have to go to Chiado. I just love the vibe and the energy in this place, the little cafes, restaurants and shopping at the Armazens do Chiado.

A great vibe. We went during the day and again early evening. There was great music in the streets, terrific shops and a lively buzz about the place on both occasions. Very stylish, young and cool, and great restaurants.

It has it all!. Chiado has it all: monuments, museums, shops, esplanades, terrace bars with a view (e.g., Hotel do Chiado and Hotel do Bairro Alto), bars, restaurants and a vibrant life. It is an important place to go during the day and also at night.In what regards monuments, do not miss the ruins of Carmo Covent, the elevator of Rua Augusta (same construction style as the Tour Eiffel, in Paris), and the churches, particularly the ones on top of Rua Garret, and S. Carlos (theatre). You have an underground stop called Chiado. Thus, it is easy to go there.

Lovely by the Tegas. This is gorgeous by night and during the day there's lots to see, lots of shopping at the wonderful top of the line stores, going through the cobble stone sidewalks filled with intricate patterns. There's really nothing like it. There are lots of shops, amazing architecture, restaurants, cafes the list goes on and on.
Lively, good people watching. Great shops, cafes and energy. Good to walk around in. Watch your wallet though lots of pick-picketers.

Famous area of Lisbon where you find shops, restaurants, romantic streets, etc..... The place to be in Lisbon where locals and tourists walk around. Area is usually busy and you'll enjoy as much the narrow streets of the hill as the main Avenida da Liberdade leading to the Tagus river.

Beautiful architecture makes this a great area for a stroll. A relatively flat area of Lisbon so this is a good place to take some respite from the many hills of Lisbon! The buildings are a joy to look at but the black and white paving keeps you marvelling at the ground as well. Peppered with lovely small shops and eateries to feed your inner consumer. For the seamstresses and knitters amongst you, check out all the fabric and notions shops - lovely to see the old ways are still appreciated in this European city.

Great area for shopping. We loved it here. The area buzzed and was great for both shopping and eating. There are great views over the area and when the sun starts to go down it looks amazing streaming through the narrow streets. Well worth climbing the hill.

A Delightful District. Wandering the streets was delight. Don't miss the Igreja do Carmo, now an archeological museum and a reminder of the devastation of the 1755 earthquake. Left roofless, it is still very beautiful against the blue sky.

Excellent location for drinking in history. From the black and white patterned pavements to the towering apartment blocks, every street in Chiado is interesting.
