Every cafe and restaurant is offering good quality local food and drink. There are so many mixtures of styles and yet they all compliment each other perfectly. The area is hilly and complicated to explore, but the tube station and the department stores have escalators in them, so you can learn how to navigate in a way that is easy on the calf muscles.
great neighborhood. everywhere you go in lisbon, there is a certain charm. good restaurants, a lot of pedestrians streets.

If you're into cultural and trendy spots, then this is for you.. Accessible by train, coming from Cascais, by bus, subway or walking the way up from Rossio or Cais do Sodré, you get to the cultural and historic city heart. It's a lively place during the day or by night.There's the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Pharmacy Museum and up the street Natural History Museum. You have two theaters, an Opera House. You can lounge at excellent coffee shops and esplanades, or have a gourmet experience in some of the best restaurants in town. Also have really nice vintage shops along with the trendy fashion shops. Christmas is a beautiful season with all the lights and street concerts. I recommend staying here at Chiado, either being a budget accommodation ( there are several brand new hostels) or in a boutique hotel. It's the perfect location in Lisbon!

Such a lively and beautiful part of town!. I stayed right by the main square in Chiado, and I loved it! It has GREAT bars, cafes, and restaurants! It is a lively place, but not crazy...I recommend staying somewhere close to Chiado when staying in Lisbon, its the perfect location!
Nice Square. This is a nice square above Rossi square. Its attractive and near a lot of theaters and restaurants. Also the buses and taxis stop here.

Centre of Lisbon - wonderful..... A must see... plenty of museums, walk all the way up from Rossio... excellent coffee shops serving wonderful pastries... appreciate the cobblestones with its intricate patterns.... what an experience
Go!. A must!!! For every reason! The history..the people...the sounds...the views...the options are huge. If you don't go to Chiado, you haven't seen Lisbon.

An AMAZINGUpscale'ish Shopping, Dining, Exploring, Cultural area in the Dynamic Heart of Old Lisbon. Love the Chiado area of old central Lisbon.Located in the mid to north end area of the wonderful, old world, central historic old Lisbon, the Chiado area offers a truly amazing mix of shopping, dining, cultural and historic elements and within a terrific exploration area of hilly street, hidden alley ways and secret gardens, parks and square - all of which make the area magical!!!The cross section of shops and shopping is wonderfully diverse - from very high end to common mid range chain stores (who's exterior and interior appearances look to aspire to their high end neighbours but maintain the consumer conscious pricing. There are the best of the best fashion and accessory retailers, decor and design shops, wonderful restaurants, cafe's, walk-in take out eateries, gelato cafes (a favourite), and many other that make the neighbourhood so fun to explore and experience.At one corner off the main shopping avenue, we discovered the alley of all the bookstores and book antiquariums - all of whom were having a massive sidewalk sale that afternoon. Around the next corner and down the street past some amazing cafes and a hidden open square we found the opera house and went in to do some quick gift shop shopping and see if we could get tickets for than nights performance - sold ot weeks ago unfortunately.The back to the main street, around a corner and up a steep alley past some wonderful art galleries, we found the absolutely amazing Carmo convent, a mediaeval convent that was ruined in the 1755 Lisbon earthquake, but it's architectural remnants and wonderful small museum are a true hidden gem of the area.TIP: Visit the Carmo Convent in the late afternoon going into dusk. The lighting and sunset colours on the open arches and pillars are amazing, and then when dust hits the spotlighting / uplighting turns on - making the ancient stone architecture and the ambiance... over the top magical again!Then back to the main shopping street - and at one end (for those in your group that want more shopping) where the street dips down to it's lowest elevation, there is a very nice indoor shopping mall with a great collection of unique stores - again another hidden surprise.Luckily, for the 3 days that we stayed in the old historic core, our apartment was within a few short blocks walk of the Chiado area. Needless to say we returned more than a few times to explore, shop, sit / relax and people watch.Make the Chiado area a MUST if you get the chance to visit old central Lisbon. Well worth the time and effort to find this WONDERFUL Neighbourhood. Enjoy!

Buzzing. At the heart of Lisbon, this is where you go for shopping, cafes, bookshops, restaurants & wine bars. It's very pretty and no visit to Lisbon would be complete without a wander around Chiado.

Upscale Shopping and People Watching. This captures the excitement and spirit of modern Lisbon, with the bustle of a sophisticated clientele and students living contemporary life. A great area to eat, see people, shop, and catch a sour cherry drink.
Super fun street. This street is beautiful! Full of shopping and great for an evening stroll. Like everything in Lisbon, this place too has a touch of romance to it!

Pretty so pretty!. The neighborhood is just astonishing, magic and classy, I really enjoyed it, the shops cafes, streets and plazas
Just like everywhere else in the city center has that amazing charming and beauty

Amazing place to walk. Chiado is a modern place full of shops, beautiful cafes as La Brasileira, trendy restaurants as Mini Bar. Just walk in this area is amazing. I would recommend during the afternoon.
Chiado. Amazing, by day and by night. There's just so much to do. You can walk through Rua Augusta, Rua do Ouro, shop in Armazéns do Chiado, it's amazing. outstanding really.

Fun part of Lisbon!. Chi ado is a beautiful neighborhood to walk through! The architecture and use of tile on and in the buildings was breathtaking. We found wonderful restaurants and very affordable shops.

Lovely. We loved it, nice small streets and beautyfull squares with a lot of nice shops, bars and restaurants but also many historic buildings. Superb views over the city. Our favourite neighbourhood in Lisbon

Love, love Chiado!. I love everything about this area. From its patterned pavements to its quality shops and music filled evenings. It's a great place to spend a few hours and we kept finding ourselves back in this area. The shoe shops sell quality leather shoes and boots for half the price you'd expect to pay in Italy or France. We found a couple of beautiful linen shops and all the great chain stores such as Zara & H&M. The bakeries are also incredible. Cafe Brasiliais in Chiado and well worth a visit.
Life in the Chiado. We rented an apartment here for 3 weeks and it turns out to be a perfect location. Lots of shops and restaurants and much of Lisbon ' s sights are in walking distance.

Just walk and enjoy. Great collection of shops, cafes, and restaurants. Just walk and enjoy, a great place to get lost. Make sure to get up into the hills and look for the smaller boutique shops. They are harder to find but worth it.

Fun night life!. Lively and fun area at night! We had a glass of wine outside before we went to dinner at Limoncello which is located in that area. Loved the bakeries were open afterward :) Live music was a real bonus.
Just Your Standard European Square. One of thousands of squares through out Europe with a statue in the middle, no particular reason to go there, but it's often a meeting place for tour groups. etc-
Energy and ahopping. Take the E28 or the elevator. High end shopping and charming street scenes. A great place for an afternoon walk. Walk down the hill to Baixa.
Not the most exciting place. Its not really worth walking here.. but I guess one will at some point pass it. I would rather check out the lovely beaches and see other things than visit this place.

A modern contrast to the nearby Bairro Alto & Baixa areas!. Another Lisbon area that shows off the many contrasts of the city. Ended up here at the end of a morning walking tour led by a professional guide. Lots of stores filled with all sorts of goodies; but be forewarned that it's easy to spend lots of money here if you're not careful! If you need a break from Lisbon's many historic sights plus some relief from all the cobblestone streets and hills, the Chiado area might be what you're looking for.

Loved Chiado. Loved the area of Chiado/Baixa, me and my friend went to Lisbon and I wanted to walk round the old parts of Lisbon and I am so glad we did, all the old building the patterned floor. Everything was beautiful. I loved everything about Chiado. Lovely to walk down.
Another Lisbon gem. The center of Lisbon, all pulse start from here.Down the Bairro Alto, one side with tram 28 stop and the other side with A Brasileira the Pessoa favourite coffeshop
nice atmosphere. neighbourhood with nice atmosphere (shops, restaurants, streetartists, car-free streets): vibrant during the day en safe during evenings.

Nice area. It has the statue of Ferdinand Pessoa! The A Brasilera Cafe, the first to serve Coffee from Brazil to Lisboners.They didn't quite enjoy the drink so the owner started serving a sample of coffee- BICA- resembled a fouintain- because the way that the espresso machine poured the coffee into the cup or it's an acronym beber isto com açucar- Drink this with Sugar!

A lot of charm. One of the nicest and most charming places in Lisbon. Rua Garett is a street that has been copied from Paris and all the other streets are quaint as well. Full of shops, restaurants, coffee places and bars.
Sights and shops galore.. Such a huge variety of stores and buildings, each little lane off the main streets offering even more. Put your walking shoes on and go!

Lovely Quarter to Visit in the Heart of Lisbon. Chiado is a lovely neighborhood to walk in. Nice Café (Braziliera for example) squares, shops and museums. Also visit the Convento Do Carmo ruins and have a nice view over Lisbon from the adjacent quarter of Bairro Alto.

Day or night. Probably one of the very first places you should visit in Lisbon. Very walkable, flat, shops, attractions, waterfront, cafes...not to be missed. Easy access to other older parts of the city as well.
Historic District. Very good place for going out, packed with restaurants and bars. But also very touristic, and sometimes the tourists get ripped off. Just watch out and enjoy the atmosphere.
The heart of the lower area of the old town.. Lots of cobblestone walkways, restaurants, the waterfront. Easy walking. Fewer hills than other areas.

Lively, busy, noisy place. If you want to be in the center of the action in Lisbon day or night, Chiado is you kind of place. There are nice shops, many restaurants, coffee spots and bars, lots of Fado places, sports bars, beautiful public places to hang out.
Very nice place to walk and wonder. Very nice place to walk around and take pictures of the various statues, lots of restaurants, nice place to have a coffee mod afternoon.
Nice Neighbourhood. There are a lot to visit in the neighbourhood, good variety choice of restaurant, as well as shopping. You can easily spend hours there.

Shopping and dining awesome. This is a great area to do shopping from high end stores to commercial ones. There's also many nice restaurants with great menus and bacalao. For me the best area to stay at for visiting Lisbon, close to many landmarks, main squares, and nice hotels. Very central.
Shopping. If you want to shop you should be in this neighbourhood. That's as far as any explanation can go. To call this so supreme would be a big shame to Brussels and Paris though.

A must if you visit Lisboa.. Full of restaurants, cafes, shops and reminiscent of true Lisboa culture. The Museum of Chiado is there and also the Museo da Farmacia. Within easy walk you can reach the Barrio Alto and a longer walk will take you to the Barrio da Estrella.
Hip Place. This is where you need to visit on a Friday or Saturday night. Lots of fun and action but all in a good way.
Great atmosphere and restaurants . You can easily spend hours here there are so many shops and restaurants. You should let yourself get lost down the streets and see where you end up.
Great place to shop. Hustle and bustle is everywhere. Spend a day walking around, shopping, drinking wine, and come back at night for a good time.
Lots of bars restaurants shops perfect. Very accessible to all areas, metro easy from airport, tram 28 stops in Chiado. Lots of bars, restaurants and shops perfect location

A different feel. Part of the city with so much history you should see. They have beautiful churches in almost every block. The energy is different from the rest of Lisbon. Everything is packed together and worth a walk through.

Ideal spot to wander, shop, and indulge.. Located on one of Lisbon's 7 hills, Chiado offers many opportunities to explore an area filled with music, art, pastries, unbelievable chocolate, and wine bars. Wear comfortable walking shoes, don your FitBits and don't worry about caloric intake. Lisbon's 7 hills is your stair-master.
Loved it here. we ate in this area a few times, wandered the streets, visited cafe's and watched the street entertainment, very nice.

Great for shopping, coffee, breakfast, lunch or dinner, and people watching. Great shopping, coffee, people watching. Many lovely restaurants hidden in the small streets. One of the best pasteis de nata by the square. Wear comfortable shoes for the hill walks!
Nice area. Nice area with a lot of cafes and shops. Also nice in the evening with streetartists and music. Something for everyone
Great sight to visit. Great area to walk around daytime or night time. Lots pf places to eat and drinks. Lots of markets/shops to do your shopping.

One of the big three...Aliamanu, Barrio Alto, and Chiado...must visits. Fun district to roam around in...shops, food, parks and small ally ways. Take sturdy shoes and rest from time to time. Time should not hurry you along. Have a good time shopping for things you don't need but find pretty. Enjoy and drink more wine!

Shopping District on Your Way to the Barrio Alto. The Chiado District is set between the Flat Centre of Baixa and the High Hill of the Barrio Alto to the West. The Area has a Metro Station just up from Rossio Square where you will find opposite the Main Exit the Famous Cafe named ' A Brasilia ' . The Main Street is Rua Garrett which is full of High end Shops, Boutiques and Restaurants with a Main Square Outside the Metro Station of Baixa Chiado that has as its Centre Piece a Large Monument attracting a Mixture of old & young alike who seem to use this place as somewhere to just relax, meet up and chat and watch the world Go by.

Lovely. Chiado is often described as a more upper class area and it certainly lives up to that reputation.It has a beautiful square, a metro that connects you to several places within Lisbon.The shops range from mid range to hih end designers. My favourite shop was 1shop which is a local shop but the clothes were of great quality and very cheap.There are plenty of places to eat and the pattiseries were amazing. You have to try the custard nata they are very yummy.The area is also close to Restores and Rossio both of which have great places to see and eat and all 3 are definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon.There is also the famous Santa Justa lift which is based around this area and gives great viewpoints for photos of the whole city.There is also a nice little shopping center which I unfortunately did not get an opportunity to visit but looked nice.The best way to travel is the metro but I have to admit the taxis are not that expensive at all.

Chiado District - Great Strolling Place. We spent several evenings strolling the park-like boulevard in the Chiado neighborhood. Loved stopping at the little bars and listening to the music at some. Great shopping also.

Lisbon's phoenix. One of Lisbon most active and pleasant neighborhoods. Suffered many transformations throughout the years, in the earthquake first, and then with the fire in the late '80, but always managed to reinvent itself as a trendy and appealing space. A 2 or 3 hour walk in Chiado is essential to any Lisbon visit.
The old shoping area of Lisbon. The old shoping area of Lisbon now completely modified... but still ancient, historical and beautiful.

The heart of downtown Lisbon. By day a great place to hang out and people watch, by night a plethora of choice for eating out . Linking the shopping area of the central Biaxa area to the Bairro Alto, Chiado has many theatres, churches and Museums and lots of delightful cafes including the famour A Brasileira cafe in Rua Garret, and Tavares in Rua Misericordia, both from the early 20th century and worth a visit if you don't mind the tourist scrum.

The Beautiful Chiado. Chiado is one of the hipster areas in Lisbon. Full of shops and places to eat. If you go there you must try the Santini Icecreams. They are considered the best in the World made with a secret recepy from the santini family. Even King Juan Carlos of Spain goes there when he was in Portugal.
Have your camera handy. So many gorgeous buildings and photo opportunities. Wonderful shops and cafes. A really nice part of town, worth a visit!
Chiado. Chiado is a nice laid back quarter definitely worth visiting. There is quite a bit of history here as well as shops, cafés etc but I wouldn't plan to stay much longer than an hour or so.
Nice place. If you're in Lisbon and have free 30 minutes take a visit to Chiado, a nice place to visit and shopping.
Great area. Wonderful place full of eclectic shops and restaurants, some beautiful antique shops, Great vibe and full of interesting places to eat, drink and see.

Ok, but be careful of pickpockets. Not so keen on this place. Lots of shops, pretty pricey and very touristy. We were robbed here as well, so that might have coloured my judgement. Be careful, and if you must use an ATM, don't do it on the street, enter the bank building
Lovely vibe. Super lively place, lots of great shops and restaurants. Love being able to sit outside have a few drinks and people watch. Lots of local entertainers on the streets as well.

Great authentic neighborhood! . Great neighborhood in Lisbon, worth a visit during the early evening to enjoy the bars and stores and to take a walk through an authentic district with locals and unpretentious nightlife. Good restaurants too.

5 days break in Lisbon. In Chiado area you have 2 (3) metrostations (Restauradores and Baixa-Chiado) from ewhere it is easy to buy the best transportcard;Lisbon transport networks,can be used on all city transports.When you get tired on shops in this area continue either to Bairro Alto or explore the surrondings i Lisbon with this daycard and get lost

just beautiful like always. love Lisboa
nice city
always a pleasure to come back
advice every one to visit this beautiful Portuguese city

Not bad for a walk!. Being one of the main attraction of the city, it's good to take a walk there especially if this is your first time to Lisbon. It's relaxing to have a drink at the patio of a restaurant in the area, although I'd suggest skipping the meals there (typical concerns at touristy areas - markup price, too crowded, etc).

Great for a wander. It's busy and vibrant at night with lots of shops, bars, restaurants, and side streets to explore. Quite easy to get lost if you're looking for somewhere specific, but there are plenty of people to ask.
worth to 'climb' there:-). great atmosphere, plenty of small street full with good restaurants,some good local design boutiques(rua do Norte)
Chiado is fun. Chiado is a quarter of Lisboa with a lot of tipical bars and restaurants. Something like French Quarter in New Orleans-USA, but it is very safe.

Urban culture. If your objective is to know Lisbon, Chiado is a good place to start. It's very cultural, but also very trendy. Has a great variety of brands for the shopping fans, but you can also enjoy the variety of different people, with their own style and way of living. Worth the visit, especially if seen with curious eyes (searching even the most hidden streets)

Shouldn't miss it. Chiado is a very interesting place to visit. Packed with people from different ages and nationalities, it’s the perfect spot to go shopping, have lunch, tea or a drink, and visit some monuments, like Convento do Carmo. The view from up there is superb. Just around the corner there’s Bairro Alto

One window for the past. Former shopping and high classes residential area of Lisbon, Chiado maintains its charm. Don't forget the old Brasileira café, with its sitting statue of the poet Fernando Pessoa.
worthy place to visit. Must See area one of the busiest in Lisbon with shops and restaurants and close to Tagus river. Ultimate place to be with many things to do and places to visit. Loved it

Just....lovely. Lovely and lively neighbourhood.lots of shops and cafes.we really enjoyed walking and getting lost in chiado.ladies please wear comfortable shoes.the streets are paved and it does get sloppy in some areas.
Interesting, quaint area. Old Lisbon.. Very hilly, wear sneakers only. Antique shops, variety of shops, small cafés, all food in Lisbon was good. Interesting area.

Great location to stay. This is a great centeralized location if you are staying in Lisbon. You are near public transport (trains to Cascais and Sintra as well). Lots are great little markets and food stops.

The hip place to hang out in Lisbon. This area is definitely the place to hang out especially if you are young. There is a lot of action, great restaurants, cool wine bars and lots of people. It is a great place to shop and wander the streets. You can sit outside at numerous cafes and enjoy some outdoor music and entertainment. Upscale stores but not over the top.

Hip neighbourhood with some history. A hip neighbourhood with nice shops and a good atmosphere even though crowded with tourists all year long!!!! mandatory: picture beside the statue of Fernando Pessoa, have a coffe in the oldest cafe of Lisboa, shopping for hip shoes and clothes. Nice day! worth it when the weather is not too hot. Access very easy either by metro or tram.
Fun place. It's a fun square with lot's of places to see and visit in walking distance. Good place to start exploring the city!

Fancy shops, trendy bars and interesting streets. Bohemian quarter with renowned shops, restaurants, cafes, bars and old buildings!. Probably named after António Ribeiro (c.1520–1591), a popular poet who lived in the area and whose nickname was "chiado" ("squeak"). A bronze statue of the poet was placed in the Chiado Square in 1925. An important cultural area, with several museums and theatres (including the Portuguese Opera House).The most well-known café of Chiado is "A Brasileira", famous for having had poet Fernando Pessoa mingling with the people. A statue stands out there and it is widely appreciated both by the Portuguese and tourists.Narrow typical streets with great shops, elevators, restaurants, cafes and bars! Underground station is Baixa-Chiado!

Make sure you spend time in this area of the city. Trendy , happening part of the city. Many shops , restaurants, and small largos. Lots of animation around happy hour. Many excellent restaurants and bars.

About 1 block from the custard shop is a Fado bar that was featured in Anthony Bourdain's Lisbon episode. I went there and had an amazing great time! I joined a table that included people visiting from Amsterdam and Italy as well as a local Fado legend! Whatever your schedule is you should definitely spend some time in the Chiado.

Upmarket shopping in two parts. Chiado is one of the principal shopping precincts of Lisbon and to me it seemed to be in two distinct sections: a multi-storey mall that links to the Baixa downtown area via escalators (or the Elevador de Santa Justa) and the Rua Garrett, which leads you to Barrio Alto. Both were popular with shoppers and strollers when we visited but for my mind - and with other tourists in mind - Rue Garrett is where it's at. The shopping mall is so anonymous it could be anyway. Rua Garrett on the other hand is full of character, pedestrian friendly, and lined with elegant, attractive buildings. Two stores that we especially liked were 'Bertrand' and 'Paris em Lisbon'. The former is said to be the oldest bookshop in the world, has lots of books in English, and browsing here was a much more pleasurable experience than doing so at Portugal's other famous bookshop, Livraria Lello & Irmao in Porto. The latter is a very classy fabric shop selling materials, linen etc of the highest quality.  There are no shortage of cafes and restaurants, though we were disappointed with our experience at the well-known Cafe Brasiliera.

Chiado, overlook of the city of lisbon. Lots of beautiful views, red tile roofs, friendly and safe city. My first day there, we went to the overlook at Chiado to take pictures. Some of the churches we entered asked for a small donation. Cheap, very affordable to see these places. Most of the old churches had beggars outside with a cup. But they don't bother you. It is fine to give them a few coins. Most of them are old, missing limbs. But none were aggressive. If you're in the area, visiting these churches and the chiada overlook is a must!

Not to be missed, but bring a comfortable pair of walking shoes for the hills!. Chiado is a fun and charming area in the center of "old Lisbon", although it mixes both the old and the new. There is lots of shopping in the area, along with cafes and museums. It is also eat to access via the new Baixa-Chiado station. In addition to visiting Chiado square and the Museu do Carmo, have a coffee in the "A Brasileira" (next to Camões square), which is popular with tourists and locals alike, and where the poet Fernando Pessoa often visited. If you do down Rua do Carmo, you will quickly be in the downtown area of Rossio Square, so everything is nearby (including the sea!) There is plenty to see and do, so don't miss out!

Sad songs - deeply moving. You see I feel sad when you're sadI feel glad when you're gladIf you only knew what I'm going throughI just can't smile without youI love it - I just don't understand what they feel sad about as they live in such a wonderful place
Lively area. Convenient to shopping and short walk to beach front walk/jog area all along the rivers coast; large market for food, fish (market) flowers, buses, trains & ferry boats.

Lively square surrounded by good cafes/restaurants. This was our first stop after arriving in the evening. We grabbed a cocktail at the tiny bar in the square then found the best pasteis of our visit nearby. Worth a visit, particularly in the evening as folks gather and socialize.

The Elevator. Whilst wanding around the narrow streets we stumbled upon this elevator (small version of the Eifel tower!). It looked completely out of place but was interesting to see. It was black in colour and I could see a lift and stairs inside. I could see people at the top looking at the views but there was a queue so we gave it a miss.

gorgeous town but be careful what footwear you take.. Lots to see and do in Chiado. There's a great musical vibe around the town with buskers and pop up musicians. Weather was really warm in April so locals and tourists were out and about creating a good buzz. So many eateries, in particular pastry cafes. it was nice to visit some of the more traditional cafes, they can be a bit touristy but I am a tourist so when in Rome...a couple of things to note that may be useful. Chiado and much of inner Lisbon is sited on steep hills. I think this would be difficult for people with wheelchairs or large prams or people with any mobility issues. What makes this situation even more tricky is that all of the pavements are made of small square cobbles which are really slippy unless you are wearing rubber soles. After falling over twice, i bought a pair of converse type shoes which were ideal. Would highly recommend but think about your footwear.

Too many panhandlers. The city center is pleasant, the old houses a dream to watch but the numerous pizza joints in the middle of the streets should be forbidden. Every 2 meters some "pseudo artists" who wish to take your pocket change. its a disgrace for this beautiful city.
Worth a visit. We walked through here a few times during our stay in Lisbon. great place to sit and have a coffee or beer and people watch. Lovely authentic atmosphere and some nice shops.
Crowded. It's a nice place, but on weekends it gets crowded. Lots of stores and cafés.Advice: wear comfortable shoes.

The soul of Lisbon. People watching, shops, restaurants, and more. Locals with tourists. The prices are now even less than when I was there and the dollar to Euro exchange is more favorable. Wander the neighborhood after getting your fill of shopping and food.
A fun area. This area is large, with fantastic architecture and lot's of restaurants. Touristy but a must to visit if you are in the city.

Great shopping and people watching.... Not far from where we are staying in the Barrio Alto, there are tons of stand alone shops and the mall at the end of Rua Garrett. We shopped, enjoyed a drink and a street performing band that was perfectly in tune with the kind of day that it was, a sunny, laid back Saturday around noon; then off to lunch at a bistro just round the corner, perfect!
Great place to visit. This area has great restaraunts and fun to wonder around in the shops. We stayed in this neighborhood which was. Great location.

Heart of Lisbon. If you are visiting Lisbon, you can't miss it. The tourists, the street performers, the shops and the ever-slightly feel that you are walking in a place that was rather different 100 years ago. Yes, Chiado was and is the heart of Lisbon, although the artists that used to live there have moved a long time ago (real state prices and stuff...). If you go East you will reach Rossio, if you go West you will reach Praca Luis de Camoes, where the statue of Portugal's greatest poet lays and if you go South you will eventually reach Cais do Sodre.
Good area for restaurants. Trams and trains in easy reach. Nice area and some streets quiet at night. Close to all areas except Alfama but Tram will take you there.

Lisbon's Core. Every tour seems to begin, end or meander through this square, so it's hard to miss. A great place to spend some time people watching or to grab a bite to eat or just browsing through the shops.

Soho in Lisbon. This is what Soho must have been like before gentrification. Go there and go now, before all the well-to-do apartment buildings start opening up and the atmosphere changes. It is still rough in the edges, but that is the charm. Lots of boutiques with everything you will need, lots of stores...lots and lots of restaurants and cafes...loved it.

Truly gorgeous part of Lisbon city. Visiting Lisbon without going to the Chiado would be a shame. Much of it was burnt down quite some years ago and rebuilt in the original style of architecture with some new modern buildings tucked away in the side streets. It is worth spending half a day walking around, visiting cafes or a restaurant, through the many squares that border it and connecting streets. There are expensive brand name shops in this district, which borders on theatre land, plus a modern art museum. We were there on a Sunday when an excellent street band entertained visitors. Approaching Baixa-Chiado on foot from Rossio or Placa da Figueira requires walking up steep narrow roads through rundown parts that might be considered characterful. There is much to see in this area generally. Recommend visiting on a weekend when not too hot.

Shops. Nice little boutiques, a must if you like to shop and don't necessary want to go to H&M or Zara. The historical tramline 28 goes through Chiado, which is perfect to combine shopping and sightseeing
Lovely slice of old Lisbon..... A lovely evening spent watching day turn into night, with churches galore, mingling with locals and sampling the cafes and bars.
To be seen. Very central to it all. Includes exclusive shopping as well as bars and restaurants that should not be missed. Get off at Baicha Chiado Metro or stop on the 28 tramway.

Great place with shopping and restaurants. We were staying in Baixa and Chiado is within walking distance from our hotel. Here you can find lots of restaurants and boutiques and of course the famous Garrett Street. We have done some of our shopping here.

chic hill of cafes, bars and shops. As you climb the hill in the commercial area, enjoy the views and atmosphere. Often street performers or bands will be about and plenty of shops or cafes to stop in and relax.

average and hard to find. firstly note- it does not say chiado so hard to find. There is a very mediocre temporary exhibition for some unknown reason linked with a student studying in Wales linked with the holocaust- which I skipped as no interest. Get beyond that- up 2 floors and you find their permanent collection which is interesting and worth going to. This is also included with your Lisbon card (worth buying for free museum entry and free transport).
Centrally located. Our hotel was in Chiado. Very centrally located. Easy to get to Metro, buses, trams, shopping, dining, ...
Great part of town to explore. Shops and cafes are great. The streets are full of people and it's a lively atmosphere. Shop at Sapateria do Carmo and Lavaria do Ulisses
Old town. this is the old town...you go back centuries ago when you visit this...the streets, churches, very good shops, theatre, you must go to the cafe "Brazileira"...

When in Lisbon...you must go to Baixa-Chiado!. Not going to Baixa-Chiado would be equivalent to going to New York and never visiting Manhattan, seriously, it's a must! Baixa-Chiado is where you'll find street performers, street meat (food stands), fine dining and lots of shopping. It's also pretty close to Bairro Alto, THE place for nightlife. I highly recommend for anyone visiting Lisbon.
Good neighborhood.... The Neighborhood of Baixa-Chiado definitely worth the visit as you can find out a lot of attractions and a lot of nice sites where to restore and have a great lunch/dinner...

A must!. Chiado is a must in the city of Lisbon. It has the most beautiful dynamic environment counting with street artists, shops, cafes... (Remember that the shops close at 7pm, though). Like the rest of downtown, you have to visit it to capture the real nature of Lisbon. There, you can also see a lot of historical buildings like churches. You can also find plenty of museums.Visit it! You won't regret.Bonus: when staying in Lisbon you can't not go to Cascais. Only a trip of train separates you from Cais do Sodré and Cascais. (Approximately 30 minutes). The village, right by the train stop is full of shops, cafes, little hidden beaches (such as Praia da Rainha-beach of the Queen in Portuguese), McDonald's, a mall, museums (Cidadela de Cascais, Condes de Castro Guimarães...). You have to visit Santa Marta Lighthouse and Museum too. I highly recommend you going!

Good enough for an afternoon stroll, but go to Biarra alto in evening.. Chiado is downtown Lisbon where you can take in some shopping and smaple the port in the deli shops. There are street performers and some independant fashion stores as well as all the usual names like Zara....which is definitley cheaper in Portugal then in the u.k.! If you walk through Chiado metro station to the exit at top of the escalaltors. it brings you out near Biarra Alta which has great bars that get going after 9pm, and many have live bands playing until the early morning. If you walk up the stairs by the side of the Metro you will see a hadful of designer shops like Boss and Massimo Dutti and a fab restaurant on Salamanca street called "Salamanca!" which is a great venue for a romantic meal with the most polite attentive staff you will enconter and delicious food in a swanky environment but not for a swanky price!

the renewed old center. chiado is the shopping area both for locals and tourists, close to good restaurants, and with shops for every taste and cost. well worth some hours and than dinner at bairro alto

The city life. A beautiful place to enjoy the city life of Lisbon .. with a beautiful statue beside the upstairs of metro station of the man who named the place with his name .. and a huge statue in the center of square which people take photos and enjoy with Flocks of pigeons

Great place for shopping!. If you like shopping, Chiado is the place for you! With a lot of big international shops, but also little local boutiques, any shopping lover will find what they are looking for! Also, a lot shops have sales on their products most of the time, so definitely check it out :)

A nice quarter of the old Lisbon. Chiado has been devastated by a fire some years ago and for a period it seemed that it would not recovered its former charm. But it did. It has resurrected some of the ancient shops as well as its magnificent churches which now live side by side withthe new buildings designed bu a well know architect (Siza Vieira). Visit also also of the XVIII neighborhood, the «Baixa» , plus on the upper side the Bairro Alto. By foot and looking around.

Great to take a walk. Chiado is one of the olddest and more ellegant places in Lisbon. You can find class shops it's true, but you can also find a lot of people on the street laughing and enjoying a walk, you can have an ice cream or a cupcake or you can just appreciate. Enjoy.

Fado in Chiado. We thoroughly enjoyed this Fado performance. The singers, a young man and a young woman, as well as the musicians, put on a wonderful show. They were all extremely talented and very entertaining.
Best place in Lisbon to hangout. Great place with city life, food, cultural and to close to best views over city and river and from Bairro Alto's night life

THE MOST SOPHISTICATED AREA IN LISBON. Chiado is a must for Lisbon visitors. This is where you can find the best restaurants in the city, lots of medium/high quality restaurants as an alternative (and dozens of cheap restaurants also), 3 or 4 theatres, lots of shops, churches to visit, the iconic Brasileira, elevador de Santa Justa, and a lot more.The gay area with lots of Bars is 5 min walk away. You can also walk to the Tagus river (5 min walk).In terms of acomodation, there are not many hotels. I would sugest Hotel do Bairro Alto and Hotel do Chiado, for instance, but theee are not many more. You can also try a good brand of serviced apartments, like Lisbon Best Apartments or Lisbon serviced apartments.

SHOPPER'S PARADISE. OK--if you love Miu Miu, Michael Kors, Lacoste, etc --This is the place to get your shop on, you iwll be treated to world class shops as well as gorgeous statues and squares and those lovely buildings some with tiled facades. In this area are wondrous sites like the Eden theater which boasts full tropical palms under glass--overlooking the street--you can SEE these palms though the glass and they are full size!! There are also many museums and this area is where the red and blue line buses stop to let passengers on or off. (we got off of the hop on , hop off bus here) around the corner are gorgeous churches and squares we even saw a commercial being made in one square with a giant teddy bear. Be aware that there are gypsies in this area so guard your purses and belonging well as there are pick pockets--in fact it is best to have a money belt (IMO) and to keep it tucked in underneath your clothing--pickpockets like things that swing free or are in pockets-the closer you carry your valuables the less of a target you will be, avoid crowded areas where people can brush up against you and do not allow strangers to hug or tug on you or your clothing.That said, look around, there are mumerous museums and even city buildings are gorgeous and wonderfully carved. I did not shop at any of these stores as I had a destination--instead I people watched and admired all of the buildings--perhaps another time when both my pocketbook and my feet did not have other plans!!
LISBOA. just enjoy walking around this elegant part of lisboa for shopping-it so nice-just dont mind all people that offer you drugs
Chiado. On the Metro, and well worth a visit. This old part of the city is a favourite with tourists. Great shops and great restaurants and small pubs.

Amazing place to be at - evenings and nights. This place is amazing. Metro station comes out to this bustling night life. feels safe and old trams just outside the stop to take a trip to Bairro Alto. the tram ride around this area is amazing day or night. Eat, drink everything. Chiado Shopping for branded restaurants and shops just down the lane. there are 2 of the most famous cafe or bar just behind the station. worth a visit if in Lisbon. Best way via Metro to reach here or a stroll from Terreiro da Paco to Rossio square and then up the hill to Baixa Chiado...

Largo do Chiado: live musicians by the street, very skilled street dancers, and the < a brasileira >. such a traditional and cosmopolitan square joined to Largo de Camōes. A perfect place to be in a happy hour not in a hurry. Metro a few steps from A Brasileira. The place where I felt most the Portuguese soul.
Has a bit of everything.. Chia do has a variety of shops, bars and restaurants. The place to go in the evenings for supper and during the day for coffee and people watching.

History and fashion. In chiado we could see fashion and history all together! Between the restaurants and bars we can find the best views, great historic and scenic places like the best fashion shops in the world.
Where things happen. Walk as much as you can through Chiado streets - you'll certainly find quite special places to eat and shop.
largo de chiado. Go there for fado,the are palace which holds fado shows,it was a nice experience and I thought that maybe MARIZA started her career there.
Chiado. Chiado is a great neighbourhood! If you want to buy some (expensive) cool stuff, wanna go to Zara or H&M, Chiado is a great location!
chiado. wonderful place in the heart of the city,old and at the same time full of shops and restaurants.make it big
Lovely Neighbourhood!!. Went to Lisbon on a girlie weekend and stayed in a hostel in the Chiado area. Really nice area and we felt really safe. Loads of things to see and do.

Nice Neighborhood. Really interesting neighborhood, close to all of Lisbons famous tourist attractions and sites. In Chiado you will enjoy great food at amazing prices as you get greal value for the little money that you will pay.
Classic Lisbon. Part of what gives Lisbon such charm. Worth an afternoon of strolling around. Stop for coffee in the Brasiliero or sample Port Wine at the Solar.
Exellent food and service. Food was delicious , service was excellent cant believe how cheap it was . Really good value for my money . Would defiantly go back .
Nice!. Really nice neighborhood with some of the important attractions you've got to see when in Lisbon! Definitely visit it!!

Convenient Downtown Location. My wife and I visited here on a recent trip to Lisbon. Chiado offers a very convenient location that is close to most of downtown Lisbon's favorite attractions. It is only a short walking distance to the waterfront and offers a nice variety of shopping. Chiado is situated fairly high in the city and its many shops and hotels offer tremendous views. We particularly enjoyed exploring all the back streets and historic sites.
Amazing suburb. Very nice, cozy streets, full of history and charm. Lots of nice shops and good cafés. A walk there is a must, as well as to the adjacent Bairro Alto.

Great area to walk around Lisbon . Chiado is an area very close to barrio alto. All by itself though it is a very charming neighborhood and has lots of personality at all hours of the day. Restaurants line the streets and cafes etc. it is a very vibrant area and my wife and I spent lots of time enjoying the sites and the tiled buildings littered around the area.

Stay out until all hours of the night!. A vibrant, energetic, and social part of Lisbon. Endless options for great food, bars, shopping and nightlife. Friendly and safe, well lit and an amazing energy to be felt.

Include this area in your walk around Lisbon. Chiado has shopping, cultural attractions, restaruants, and atmosphere. The blue and green metro lines stop at the Chiado metro station. It is also centralized so from here you can walk to other great spots in all directions including the Baixa and Bairro Alto.
Chiado. Took elevator to Carmo and walked to Chiado alto all the way down to sea. Very pleasant walk with lovely buildings and shops to browse into

Old spirit of Lisbon. Chiado is the gate to the Bairro alto. Very active a night due to the rich nightlife in that area. Lots of bars and pitoresque restaurants. Lots of turists and locals. Drinking and partying on the tight streets of the bairro alto.
Best place to be!. The Old town of Lisbon. The best place to be in Lisbon. From the street performance, designers shop, souveniers, light and the old building. You can find everything in this place.
The most lively quarter in town. The Chiado is one of the most lively quarters in Lisbone, full of shops, street musicians and artists, charming squares and the flavour of the city.
Great place to wander. Great place to wander around and leads to the main pedestrian area. Electric trams in Lisbon are fantastic

chic, cool chiado. Took friends on a tour of this lovely, ornate neighborhood with old fashioned street lamps, Manueline architecture, winding cobbled streets and beautiful shops.Its Lisbon s Park Ave.and a great place to meander and gaze at while sipping a coffee.
You may end up here!. you eventually end up here in your tour of Lisbon and you can absorb everything this spot has to offer!
time to shop. Great place to shop.There are so many stores and restaurants to do it or just walk and enjoy those beautiful streets.

Must See Area. The Chiado is a must see area. You definitely need to plan for an afternoon and evening. There are so many stores and restaurants to stop in to. You can get down in this area via the hop on and off tour bus. Nice views of the coast line too. You can't miss this area. So much history around to see too.
lovely neighborhood. you may say too crowded - but it is a nice place to hang out. great little restaurants hidden in side streets. great boutiques and shops.
Wonderful. Lively, vibrant district of the portuguese capital. Nice shops, buildings, pastry shops and cafés. Lisbon is surely alive all day round! By day and night, a place not to miss.
Nice place. Good area to stroll around, shops and cafes. Certainly worth a walk during the day, while at night the areas near the sea are maybe better.

Atmospheric. Went to Chiado to see a Fado show... really nice neighbourhood, quite authentic and atmospheric. Winding streets and on a hill so be prepared to walk. But you do find some jewels like we found a nice café-restaurant and ended up having dinner and getting a bit tipsy as we had the whole bottle of wine between the two of us - not usual for us. Also a very nice and ancient bookshop in this area - Livraria Bertrand on Rua Garett.

Chiado. Chiado is where most restaurants and bars are in Lisbon City Centre. Fernando Pessoa, the most important poet in Portuguese literature, was frequent seen in the cafes in the neighbourhood. Today we can take a picture it his statue on front of the Brasileira Cafe. A must when visiting Lisbon.
Chic Chiado. It's a great area to walk around and pop in and out of shops. Lots of local stuff, brands, shopping, street cafes and a great place to hang about.
Great area. Great way to spend a few hours by wandering all the streets and lanes. So much on offer you wont be dissapointed

Cool area....will return. We wandered thru this cool neighborhood at night looking for our restaurant and enjoyed it so much we returned the next day in the daylight. Trendy shops, hip restaurants, great street scene.

Historical site. a must see area in downtown Lisbon. After a huge fire in the 90s this area is totally rebuilt and revived. You will find stores, cafes, and opportunity to walk into important Portuguese history paths.
Soak it up. this area is vibrant and bustling, great place to walk through at various times it comes alive. There are some fabulous cafes with the most fantastic window displays of cakes and pastries

Great shops and Better restaurants. If you visit Lisbon head here after dark for shops open late and some incredible restaurants. My favorite was Brasserie de L’Entrecôte which has the best steak I have had. The side walks are narrow and they are made of marble pieces so wear shoes you can walk in.

vivid and various. a district not to miss while in lisbon. Chiado is the door to barrio alto or high town. many shops from Hermès to Zara for all tastes and budgets. Typical ancient shops to be seen too, climbing the street will take you to more typical places with lovely bars and restaurants. do not hesitate to take a cable car for the fun, what ever the destination they will drive you back sooner or later. The one to the Basilica is on of the most interesting for its scenictrip...ladies, avoid high heel shoes there...

Great place for a walking. Chiado it is a part of the Lisbon city full of traditional shops, coffees, restaurants, old buildings, street musicians, etc...It is a fantastic place for a nice and quiet walk ... Magic place that you must visit in Lisbon.
Pricy Stores. You can find these brands and price everywhere else but this is a cool street to spend few hours after dinner.

Vibrant part of Lisbon. Very nice part of city to walk with a lot of shops and cafes and restaurants. Bit expensive and touristy for my taste as you can find gems in other parts of the city, but worth the visit.

CHIADO a great walk and shop. A magical area, with nice stores, quaint cafés and restaurants, street musicians and lots of atmosphere. Don't just stay on the main street (Rua Garret), venture into some of the side streets for more goodies!
vibrant. The most vibrant part of Lisbon! It's in the middle and bustling with activities. Lots of shops (for clothes) and buskers.

A piece of history and art. This is well worth the visit. A bit expansive regarding some cafes, but...still worth it.
Shops, theaters monuments, every street is a monument!!
Don't miss it, either you are portuguese or not!
Central Lisbon. This is the most central part of the city, where yo can acess to all kind of things (good restaurants, good shops, etc.,)
Lovely shops and cafes. A great place to have a stroll, shop and have a coffee. Some smaller shops are really interesting and catch your eye, so keep them wide open :)
Emblematic are of Lisbon. Chiado is a very fashionable are of Lisbon, great coffee shops and street shopping, cultural atmosphere with street musicians and very charming of buildings.

Shopping galore. Chiado is great for restaurants, street life and shopping. Beware of pick pockets throughout the city. And beggars are everywhere. Ate at a restaurant called U Chiado. It was fabulous. Medium to High price but elegant for a special night with great seafood. Try the octopus. A great area to see the different architecture and to visit some churches.

Lisbon hotspot for shopping and cultural sights!. Stepping out of the Baixa-Chiado metro station, you are in charming Chiado district ! An elegant district of old-style famous cafes, bookshops, art jewelry shops, and international brand boutiques. "A Brasileira" is a very popular cafe of Chiado among tourists because of having had famous poet Fernando Pessoa among its customers. The Chiado is also an important cultural area, with several museums, churches and theaters. This area reformed after a severe fire in 1988.It is an excellent place to walk up and down, sightseeing and window-shopping ! Don't forget to return to neighboring Bairro Alto at night for its vibrant nightlife, restaurants, and bars ! Also don't miss the popular tram 28 which passes by.

Great Lisbon neighborhood. We stayed in Chiado at the beginning of November and loved the area. it was just a stroll or short tram or Metro ride from anywhere in Lisbon. Historic architecture, great people watching and lots to do. Warning, it can be noisy with the crowds out enjoying themselves, but you get the real Lisbon in exchange.
Good place for shopping. You have lots of stores and shops in Chaido. You can see the moll done in the "old" stores of Grandella who have been destroyed by a fire in 1988.
Colourful. Central area, a lot of churches, next to Bairro Alto, lots of restaurants and shops, generally nice to walk around.
Love it. A nice bustling area where locals and tourists mix. Nice place to get a bite to eat. Really pretty at night with all the lights on.
make sure you cab/tram up hill and walk downhill!. it's a nice area of town ..nice shopping and eats ..like La Braiseleira, Armazens Chiado mall, a couple of churches etc.

Perfect for a nice walk. This is together with Bairro alto the excellent place to feel the city. Just walk around, do not use the map and get surprised by wonderfull vieuws, Charming houses wondefull churches and do not forget to stop at cafe brasiliero, a must stop place.

The buzz of Lisbon. Chiado is where everyone is going in Lisbon. A for a good reason. This is the place where you can do a lot of things, visit monuments, shop, see some stunning views of Lisbon, stay out in a café, see the vibrancy of Lisbon, with the tourists and inhabitants passing by, It is also close to Baixa,(downtown) or Bairro Alto (an intellectual and amusement neighborhood). Lots to do, to see and enjoy in Chiado. And always the live music near the subway station exit. Must go.
Beautiful. Full of tourists and locals alike. Be careful of pickpockets. Beautiful buildings, statues, fountains and squares. Lisbon is hilly so wear good shoes
Chiado. Interesting area of old buildings and shops. Road Tram 28, very narrow streets! Enjoyed the scenery.

Hustle and bustle. Always busy with tourists and locals alike.At night there are beggars and those trying to sell illicit drugs.Usual array of tourist supplies if that is your thing.Shopping is okay with some beautiful book stores.Well heeled locals parading is always enjoyable.

Vivid and liverly district. Street life, shops, cafes and all sorts of people in a charming combination makes your pulse and shoulders go down, a smile fasten on your lips, and the conversation go easy.
Beautiful at night. Had a hotel in this part of town it's especially lovely at night. Loved the tiles. The only downside were some weird characters around, but I believe that cannot be helped.
City break. Busy, vibrant area, lots of local colour, bars, restaurants and beautiful buildings. Good central point from which to explore rest of Lisbon.

A must visit area in Lisbon. Chiado is an area full of nice bars and restaurants in Lisbon, not to mention the agreeable narrow streets to walk around.It´s located in one of the seven hills that Lisbon has. It gathers also a good number of small boutiques and shops with interesting and creative stuff and a big shopping mall called "Armazen do Chiado", where more international brands can be found as well.Two interesting places do visit for sure there are a "cafe" or the coffee shop called "A Brasileira", which has an interesting art deco style, serves tasteful coffee and has an sculpture of the famous Portuguese poet Fernando Pessoa in the front years, where they have tables outside. The other very nice place is the trend and very good restaurant called Bel Canto.But I am sure, anyone can find something interesting for his or her taste when visiting this area. It´s really not to be missed in Lisbon.
Magical & fun. Great mix between historical buildings, good shoppings and trendy cafes in the hearth of Lisboa. Some nice churches too. Ia stroll around Chiado is a must when in Lisbon.
Nice shopping, restaurants. Charming neighbourhood with good shopping and nice outdoor restaurants. Crowd is more upscale, mature than in the adjacent neighbourhood, Baixa.
For who like shopping. In the old city of Lisbon, it's a great place to walk up and down, seeing old buildings and why not, make some shopping's.

History and Charm. Chiado is now the (big) center of the old Lisbon area. Shopping, food and beverage, museums, old monuments, old churchs, culture everycorner, street music, you name it! Must go up to a terrace with a view of the magnificent river Tejo. Suggest top floor terrace at Hotel Bairro Alto.Start at Restauradores, go to Rossio, follow Rua Augusta down to the river and come back up to Chiado. You will not feel tired at all. It´s Magic!
Shop shop eat drink!. Great for shoppimg and food and drink. This area is pricier than other areas around. Looks lovely lit up at night!

The Most exciting historic and Shopping street. This is the Most pleasant street for a walk, have some Tea or coffee, eat, Shopping and see monuments and bookstores. Here you'll find the famous statue of the famous writer, poet, philosopher Fernando Pessoa, seat with him and take a picture, and also the statue of Camões the famous poet of the XVI Century

Acharming and very good ambiance quarter. It was formerly a shoping quarter, nowadays has evoluted to a charming group of streets, and squares with a very charming and beatiful environmentis worthile to walk along and feel the spirit.

cool area in Lisbon. loads to do in Chiado. Easy to access via public transport. Close to all the shopping areas including Avendia Liberdade. Really nice cafes and places to eat. near the major squares and the river. Very nice area with a great atmosphere
good area for shopping. this is a good area to do some shopping. is a good place to walk and see Lisbon streets. take comfy shoes cos' the hills in Lisbon are not very friendly to your feet.

Shop and eat. I liked walking the streets during daytime and hop in to some shops. In the evening it is different with all those waiters stopping you in your track and trying to hit on you, guess its the charm of the city and a woman travelling alone. For cheap eats, go into the foodcourt, you can have a prato variado for 4,60 which has rice n beans, fries, beef, sausage, pork, chickenwing, sparerib and fried banana plus a little salad :D
Nice. Lovely area to walk and it is very touristy. Definitely worth the walk around. Many places to eat. Great ice cream!

Great shopping area!. Beautiful boutique shops with items produced locally! Designer clothing and she's as well as textiles. It's a great way to spend some leisure time while experiencing the local culture.

Very nice but very touristic. This part of the historic center of Lisbon is really nice with a lot of options for things to do (restaurants, bakeries, caffes, museums, shopping). It isn't however, just what I was expecting from the things that I have heard of, before visiting Lisbon. It was very touristic, not exactly in a bad sense, but still it was.

Modern. Chiado is where the high street meets old town Lisbon. The shopping district of downtown Lisbon offers plenty of shops, cafes, and restaurants for all comers. Located near the old neighbourhoods this area is slightly more modern.

Lovely walk!. Lovely part of Lisbon to walk around, a great sense of culture. Some days there are little stalls that you can pick some little ornaments and books from! If you're the walking type you can walk down to Cais do Sodre from there, I do the walk occasionally with family :)

Fun neighbourhood. Great simply for walking around, stopping in restaurants, cafes, and bars. We were with 2 young children and Lisbon shares the excellent positive Mediterranean attitude towards young children!
Very nice part of town. Great part of town to just walk around and visit some beautiful churches. Also a great spot to do some shopping like at Vista Alegre for beautiful porcelain and crystal gifts.
Great area. Best area of Lisbon with square, restaurants, shopping, crowds, the elevator to go up the city. A fun place to be in a great city !

Nice historic center. Went to the square during the daytime and even at that time its cafes and restaurants were full with tourists and locals alike. The place has a lot of historical and cultural significance for lisboa. The statues of Fernando and the rapper are a must check and you will love the ambiance of the narrow cobbled shopping streets and up & downs of the hills of lisbon

Great for shopping and wondering around. Busy shopping district with all the usual international and national shops, cafes, restaurants. Not especially remarkable for a tourist unless you like/want to go shopping but great to pass the time if you are trying to kill a few hours before departing for the airport.

Typical shopping area. Good for people watching over a glass of wine. Mall could have been in any city in the U.S. There is a quiet courtyard near the chapel, hidden by storefronts, with a couple of Italian restaurants and other places to stop for a drink or bite to eat.
amazing. Everything you need is here did not dislike anything plenty to see and great places to eat you need good walking shoes lots of hills and cobbles

Style(less). It is the meeting place of the city, crowded, with nice terraces for a coffee and pastel de nata. From here you can take the subway any direction tou like. A pity that it lost a bit of its style...

Great old town vibe!. The energy of the public square is great here. I went to the beer museum in the square here and got our beers in an upside down bottle half inside of a glass (I know it sounds weird but once you see it you'll understand)"The Elevator" also has some great views of old town.

Nice Area. This is a really nice area to walk around and also has some of the best shopping, sights and eateries in Lisbon. Well worth a few hours wandering around catching the views and watching the world go by.
Must see. A fascinating part of the city to immerse yourself in. Walk the streets and take in the history of this central area.

Poets' lair. From Largo do Camoes to A Brasileira cafe you go back in time . You enjoy beautiful churches as well, cafes etc.Avoid Praca de Camoes on a weekend night. Some local rowdy youth like to congregate.
Great Neighborhood. I stayed in this area for 3 nights and it was wonderful. It's a lively place with lots of restaurants, shops, and access to anything else you want to do in Lisbon.
Great central place to stay in Lisbon. Hotel do Chiado - very central, perfect for walking about the city. Chiado has everything - cafes, shops, history and Tram 28 just round the corner

Close to Lisboa soul as it can be. Historic quarter full of modern shops, hotels and restaurants.To visit during the day.
Side by side with Bairro Alto, another historic-Popular quarter. Near to Cais do Sodré: the to latter to visit by night. Bohemic Lisbon.
Good food, Great night life. Not only are there numerous restaurants around this area, but also visit a little later when the bars around the Bairro Alto get going.
Buzzing. Very trendy area full of small bars and restaurants. Quite a few Fado establishments of varying price and quality with or without meal options.

A must to see and stay and feel i Lisbon!. you have to spend time here and let the city invade you. You will enjoy Chiado on the 24 hours of the day: since early in the morning: walk the streets, take the tram 28, enjoy the light and take wonderful pictures to the architecture and typical corners, don't lose the shopping, as you will find many international (but especially typical local design and gourmet shops); at noon, relax on the many cafes, but sit outside, listen to music played by street artists (from jazz to mornas to classical), or choose one of the terrasses to see the Tejo river lazily flowing below while having a glass of wine; find out about the many special historic buildings here, find about the 1755 earthquake, go inside the beautiful churches, sit on a bench and drink Ginjinha, a sweet licorous beverage typical from Lisbon. And choose where to go for dinner, because that can be really difficult: this is where most of the many great restaurants in the city are, always adapting, always improving, all price ranges, all audiences find something that suits. dive in!!!

The must if you are in Lisbon!. You can't say "I visited Lisbon" if you didn't cross the Chiado, one of the most typical and emblematic square of the city. Chiado called as well the "Baixa" (downtown) has numerous stories and you will be able to visit the oldest stores and take the coffee on the oldest places where Fernando Pessoa and others poets and writers did history. Chiado is a very traditional neighborhood so bring comfortable shoes, since the streets are made in "calçada a portuguese" which are group of uneven stones full of holes and quite uncomfortable for your feet if you bring heels.
Up market area with restaurants and shops on pedestrianised streets.. Well worth a visit, a smarter part of Lisbon, with elegant shops from most European countries and good local ones.
A nice place to be. This is a very popular place in the heart of Lisbon. There are shops, restaurants, landmarks and always a lot of people. It sure is a place to visit if you are in Lisbon, Portugal

This and the historic center are all Lisbon has to offer. This sq mile around historic center are all Lisbon has to offer. So take your time about it because there is nothing else, the rest of Lisbon is quite sad and boring. walk through the historic squares and down along the river and thats it. The End

fantastic. If you go to Chiado you need to go to Brasileira Cafe, where all the Portuguese writers and painters go. Fernando Pessoa wrote in that beautiful Cafe.Many shops like Hermes and others,very nice walking street.
restaurants, music, shops all in one place. A very vibrant district with all you need to have a good time. Music on the streets, numerous bars and restaurants. The most lively part of Lisbon.

Recommended area to stay in. Lovely and iconic with close proximity to most things.. We were really happy that we chose to stay in this lovely area. It was close to shops as well as bars and was not too noisy at night. If you can stay in a privately rented apartment and not hotel then do try to as it made the experience even more wonderful.
lots a stores with good deals. lots a stores ,food and anything you need ,a nice walk after a meal,esplanade all over that area i recommend to eat first than use the walk .

For Vogue lovers. Chiado is one of the most iconic and traditional neighborhoods of Lisbon. Lying between Bairro Alto and Baixa. As a cultural zone that is, here we find several theaters such as the Teatre S. Luiz, the Teatre da Trindade, and the Theatre of São Carlos, the only opera house in Portugal. Chiado became an important trade center of Lisbon, one of the most cosmopolitan and bustling areas of the Portuguese capital, is the scene of iconic events like the Vogue Fashion's Night.

Like a parade square with restaurants and shops. One of the most bustling squares in old Lisbon and there's a MacDonalds too for your hot summer's quench of thirst. Beware of mild harassment at night but you"ll do fine if you can reject them firmly yet politely.

Busy social scene plenty of great restaurants. Checkout the small local typical restaurants in the area but don't eat the cheese offered as it's not free and check your bill afterwards. Dancing and music till early in the morning. Cafes are expensive unless you go off the main streets

The old new Lisbon. This is near Rossio and Rua Augusta, easily reachable for all tourists not to miss it. It used to be an old part of Lisbon with few people but it has changed and now it is full of life night and day.There are modern and traditional shops, restaurants and bars in the narrow alleys and it is an interesting place to “get lost” and wander around.Coffee shop “A Brasileira” with Fernado Pessoa statue is there to greet everybody. There is also a famous ice cream shop: Santorini, which everybody says is the best ice cream in the world!

They don't do rain!. On a negative, we arrived and they said that we couldn't have our reserved table as it was raining? The majority of the tables are under brush canopies which the rain came through and they didn't seem to have a bad weather plan. Anyway, we were offered the alternative restaurant which had a roof but had a different menu (and price) from our chosen restaurant. However, on a positive note, this restaurant had great panoramic views, pleasant enough staff and the food and wine was lovely. The whole evening was just a bit disjointed and lost a bit of atmosphere as a result. Go when there is no rain.

Start to a night. When on city breaks it can be hard to find where to go for a good night out if you don't know the city. Come here and you'll not disappoint, literally hundreds of bars door to door so you can't not have a great time. Cheap drinks and locals casually drink hete till 4am with no trouble at all!
lovely modern shops if you want. This is modern Lisbon with chain stores and high prices etc. Great area to walk through. Lots of restaurants serving a wide variety of food options.

shops are mostly trendy; on the expensive side.. It is still a very run down neighborhood. I took a few pictures of architectural interest. There are some very interesting old book-stores with vintage prints, some boutiques with interesting clothes.

Tapas Mecca. Great vibe--SF culture meets LA beach; Birkenstocks & flip flops. Narrow alleys with lots of street life in the evening. Dinner starts @ 10 PM. Check the wine & tapas restaurants--avoid the touristico menus.
Shops, restaurant and lot of Portugal's people. One of the busiest places in Portugal, during night and days. Modern shops, typical food, people around the world with the best of Portugal.
Square in Chiado. We went to a nice square for people watching and listening to live music. There was a brilliant ice-cream/waffle/pancake/coffee shop there too!

The comercial centre of the city.. Visiting Lisbon you cannot ommit visiting Chiado. It's the commercial center of the city but it's kept exactly how it was, exactly like Lisbon at Pessoa's time.Who know's you might see him somewhere ....;)
Amazing place to walk.... Amazing place to walk... you can get lost and walk all day. A really pleasant experience. You will find a lot of places to discover.

The old "new kid" in town.... Chiado is the most fashionable district in Lisbon nowadays... but it is also one of the older and most typical ones! Fernando Pessoa was there all the time, as many of Lisbon most important facts occured there... So: plenty of history, plenty of novelty, namely as far as restaurants and bars and nice boutique hotels and cosy and trendy hostes! You cannot miss Chiado :-)
An area to visit. Everyone will most likely pass the Chiado neighborhood during a visit to Lisbon. It offers shopping, cafes, cozy squares, viewpoints, and even the old trams passing here.

Accidental session. Found o Gillins Irish pub by accident on a Monday night, don't normally go to Irish pubs when abroad but was pleasantly surprised when a trad Irish session started up but the biggest shock was that they were all Portuguese . Wow a better trad session in an Irish pub in Lisbon than at home
Great for Window shopping. Lovely area, lost of nice shops to wander between, eateries good too. Steep climb to get to if not using the lift or funicular, but worth it just to wander around
Good for a stroll. The place you should visit when in Lisbon. Beautiful buildings, good places to eat, many shops. Go for a nice stroll and enjoy the surrounding! We never felt insecure in Lisbon.

Great atmosphere. The neighborhood is very lively and nice
The long cue at the famous lift by the Eiffel's scholar a bit painful...but the view on top....wow!!!!
Tourist Shopping. Typical tourist shopping area, nothing special. Shops are in an interesting historical area, but the stores are the same you can find anywhere in the world for the most part.
Worth visiting!. Nice little shops in small streets but also the well-known streets als Rua Augusta with the shops like Bershka and Stradivarius. Good atmosphere.
Awesome atmosphere. I love the awesome atmosphere, there's a lot of people around and there's a lot of music in the street.

Shopping in Lisboa. Shopping in a beautiful neighborhood
Lots of shops, bars, restaurants for a nice stroll in the city
Beautiful antique bookstores and delicious pastry shops
Nice Neighborhood. When in Lisbon, you must visit this neighborhood! There are many great places to eat and shop and just walk around, giving you a feel of the urban life in Lisbon.

Interesting collection of Portuguese painters. Rating a museum is different from a hotel or restaurant. If you have seen many art museums than the collection of this museum is not spectaculair. However, the collection of Portuguese 18th and 19th century painters is quite good. The more modern works are less surprising. The building is worth a visit too.

different then other area's!. this part of town is very nice to go shopping. I bought designer shoes for very reasonable price! Also a very nice old, tiny little shop with leather gloves, this is already beautiful just to see it!

The Covent Garden of Lisbon!. Amazing atmosphere - Chiado never sleeps so if you don't like noisy places don't stay here!! There are hundreds of amazing shops and little restaurants and it's not hard to find a good value restaurant! Chiado is very picturesque however beware of valuables as we were almost robbed in Starbucks as we had lots of valuables such as laptops and iPads out on the table! Like any capital city you need to be careful!

Old meets the new. The heart of the city. Amazing street, filled with magic surroundings at night. Clean, easy to walk, easy to know. Close to the castle and the very old part of the city. Modern with the shops around. And culture to everyone.
Shopping. The trendy area of town with quirky shops. Think Camden town meets Convent Garden. Easy walking distance from Praca de Comercio.
nice to walk. nice to walk, interesting streets and story but a lot of shabby stuff too - one can do do some shopping but we prefer Bairro Alto (beter restaurants too)
The heart. If Lisbon should be a person, this should be its heart. You can have a bit of lots of things: food, fashion, tradition, culture. Can't miss it!
Beautiful and great for shopping. Beautiful and great for shopping.Great ice-cream on Santini and the FNAC shop is the best one in Portugal.
Fun shopping. Very energetic. Great shops....sport, home and fashion. Outdoor cafe to people watch. Also Barbarella blow dry bar!

Well worth wondering around. There are some beautiful little shops, don't judge on the outside, go in and wander around. Wear comfortable footwear as there are lots of hills and cobble streets. There are queues for popular attractions but be patient. There are many outdoor restaurants, in the evening it is very pleasant to dine outside as there may be street entertainment. Try to fit in a night to hear Fado.Side streets are interesting as there may be little shops selling antiques, jewellery, unique items, nice to visit. Of course the architecture is beautiful.

Shopping district with an historic feel. Here you find most of Central Lisbon's chain stores, but also some historical cafés and bookstores, restaurants with great views, and old churches along the edges of the neighbourhood.

Pay for a guide -it's worth it. We only had a few days in Lisbon and Portugal Trails organised a 4 hour walking tour and a guide for us called Patricia. We didn't want to shop although she would have helped us with that. We wanted to see a lot and have information about Lisbon, the people and the history. She was exceptional, pointed out tricks pickpockets use on the trams like asking you to open the window, showed us how to use the Metro and gave us local information that isn't in the guide books. We covered a large area and it was much better than wandering around not understanding what we were seeing.
The best place to eat in Lisbon. Around Chiado you have around 50 very nice restaurants to dinne. It's the best spot to go around for shopping, to stop for a cafe or just... to relax.
More alive than old town. Went to the old town but Chiado is more lively. There are more things to see and more shops to visit.

Shopping and dining!. This ditrict in central Lisbon is famous for shopping and dining, here its possible to walk around in cobblestone streets with old historical buildings with shops you havent seen before. Cameover a small shop who sold leather gloves still made the old way. Cafees and restaurants is everywhere so its possible to have a break and just people watch too.
Lively. Chiado is a suburb of Lisbon that has shops and restaurants. It's a lively suburb that's fun to explore.
Beautiful neighbourhood located on one of the hills of Lisbon.. Such a beautiful area with a street adorned with beautiful cafe's and shops! Definitely an area to visit in Lisbon! Do not miss it!

A few interesting local/independent shops amongts the global brands. Small, compact streets with interesting buildings and décor - many of the brands one can see across the world - a few more interesting local shops. Nice vibe, some street entertainment, not too many beggars (but some) - nice cafes ; prices quite low for a capital city

Atmosphere. Chiado is the name of a square and its surrounding area in the city of Lisbon, Portugal. The Chiado is located between the neighbourhoods of Bairro Alto and Baixa Pombalina.
Very unique atmosphere

Fun place. Due to our schedule, we went on Sunday afternoon. Fun to see, lots of food choices, some shops were closed. We had dinner and enjoyed the people watching. Walked down to the plaza by the water. It was packed with folks watching the huge screen TV for the Soccer Final. Exciting time to be there. Very easy to get to via the metro if you don't stay in the area. Will return to explore more of the area next time in Lisbon.
Can't miss. Can't go to Lisbon without going to Chiado. Lot's to see, great to walk around, good shopping and wonderful cafés. Not to miss the Fernando Pessoa statue, at cafe A Brasileira.

Shopping area awaiting restoration. Mainly a premium shopping area. It's abiding interest for me is the Alvara Siza Vieira designed pedestrian access route from Rua Chiado through Carmo Terrace to Largo do Carmo. This snails pace project may outlive me I fear. When completed (it's threatened to be imminent) it will make an exciting addition to the Chiado landscape. I look forward to its five star completion with eager anticipation.Garry
Lots of fun shops and walking. Great restaurants and shops around every corner. It's a great place to spend an afternoon walking around, having coffee, gelato and tapas.

Electric, Eclectic, Excentric. Chaido is a happening place. Lots of shops, bookstores, cafes and tourists. Street performers keep it interesting. Just up Garret (the main drag) from the Mall, on the left side of the street is a courtyard with three cafes. They each have good food, reasonable prices, slow-paced service, and a fine atmosphere.
