Shopping area. A lot of bustle and very crowded, this is a shopping area. We didn't really see much that we wanted to buy - it is not really for tourist shopping, but an interesting area to see. Combine it with the other neighborhoods for a walking tour just as the guidebooks suggest. Be aware the Barrio Alto doesn't open until the evening for anything!
elegant. very elegant part of lisbon. go there by day but by nights also. many restarants and street activity, street artists etc.
Truly spectacular shopping experience. The staff at every shops we went to were extremely courteous and helpful.Brilliant experience just walking on the cobberedstones street.
Five Stars! Fantastic Place. Lovely atmosphere! Great for shopping! Great cultural area to walk around! Loved the cobblestone roads! Defiantly Recommend!
Great from a ramble. Very accessible to Baixa, this area is one to get lost in. There are lots squares and alleys, stairs and "becos which reveal great cafés, restaurants and shops.
Shopping and people watching. This was a wonderful area full of shops, restaurants, coffee, bakeries and people. People were out strolling way after midnight and felt safe.
Great place for shopping and..... ...gaining an isnight to modern Lisbon. You can not miss it and it worths a visit, right in the herat of the city!
Pleasant walk. The square and its surroundings are really worth to visit. Nice buildings, statues, many opportunities to shop and to sit and eat or drink.

What a beautiful place. I was in Lisbon for 1 day and it was way too short. In Chiado you have restaurants, bars, government buildings, the beach, and historical landmarks which will take your breath away. Small streets with the most amazing colors and tiled patterns on the buildings line the block and the larger avenues littered with restaurants, bars and all the shopping a woman could ask for pepper the beautiful streets. I went up to Ascensor da Bica - Bica Funicular - to ride one of the famous trolley (this one considered to be the most picturesque in the city, the others are Ascensor do Lavra - Lavra Funicular & Ascensor da Gloria - Gloria Funicular) and it was great. Although a short ride up/down the hill, for 3 euro it is something you need to do. In addition, a must if the Elevador de Santa Justa - the Santa Justa Lift. The only vertical lift in Lisbon, you have to get a view from the top, AMAZING! All in all, I had a great stay in Lisbon and I can't wait until I have the time to go back.
Walk around, enjoy life.... Super place to walk slowly up and down..., do some shopping, have lunch or just a drink while taking advantage of the lovely atmosphere! I always come back!

Fantastic Place. Our apartment is smack in the middle of everything in Chiado. The place is always alive with plenty of people, places to eat and lots of shopping. It stays busy all night, too, so there's something for everyone all the time! We had our two-year-old daughter with us and felt very safe walking around. It was crowded, but everyone was aware of her and made sure she had space.

Bars, cafes, shops, restaurants...a bit of everything. This is an area of Lisbon that has a mix of shops,cafes, bars and restaurants. It has some impressive architecture and is a lovely place to meander and stroll around, soaking in the atmosphere. There are plenty of cafes to stop at and watch the world go by, and if you like shopping, there is an impressive mix of high end boutiques and independents shops.Mainly an area for shopping, but a lovely place to spend a few hours.

Great Architecture. This is the heart of the city with the stunning plaza, architecture, monuments and museums. There is a lot of history in this area and for some time as you stroll, you will only see the impressive structures. As you venture away from the plaza, you will find the branching streets are very similar to the districts of Bairro Alto and Chiado with culture, food and shops.I would recommend a full day here to view the structures and visit the museums.

Good shopping area. This downtown area it is a chic part of town,good restaurants and cafés for a bite,tram connection for different part of the city,very lively good street entertainers ,and street salers.
I love Chiado. It s the most funny and alive part of the city !!! Full of people and nice restaurant and shops everywhere ! I just love it I go there every weekend !

Huge Upscale Shopping Area of Lisbon. Many shops and restaurants to eat in. Mostly window shopping since they are beyond by travel budget to walk into. Good to take Santa Justa Lift to this area. It is the experience of Lisbon - which is not as crowded as a place like Madrid.

Great shopping and good food. This downtown area is considered the chic part of town. Lined by cobblestone roads where you can practically hear horse carriages from centuries past, brick streets closed off to car traffic, and cute boutique shops and cafes where you can grab a bite, this area is perfect for some window shopping and tasting some sweet treats. Several streets to visit are Rua da Prata, Rua Aurea, and Rua Augusta, which leads to the fitting entrance of the city, Arca da Triunfal (Arch of Triumph similar to the one in Paris). Spend a couple hours exploring this historic district and you'll find yourself wanting more.

Good food and friendly staff. Away from home and ready for a good meal come to Chiado.On a rainy day and ready for lunch, four of us decided to come in. We all four enjoyed our food which was presented well with good taste and quality. Staff was helpful and friendly explaining the menu to us tourist from another country.We recomend to try it while visiting Lisboa. Have fun and buen apetit.

Tourist area. A lot of amazing shopping, a lot of restaurants, just sit, have a drink and watch the people! It is beautiful in most areas of Lisbon, some you have to close your eyes, and sometimes keep them wide open! The same as any country you visit, you live the way they live. Always watch your wallets, visa and purses! We watched 2 different times of couples looking for there wallets or visa as they were pick pocketed at some time? So sad when your on holiday!

Great Shopping Place. This is a place with many stores were people go to pass time shopping,eating,many pastry shops and restaurants it is like every other door ,there is either a restaurant or a pastissiere each one the best,one can't make up the mind which one is better so much to choose so much to taste the streets are long it can be overwhelming but in a pleasant way.I recommend everyone who goes to Lisbon to visit and walk this streets.
For walkers. You will find shops, cafes, great places to see while walking. Stop at Brasileira ,the oldest cafe in town.
The bars and restaurants area. In this part of the city there are many bars and restaurants and I meet some really nice people.I liked specially the relaxed anvironment.
Good but not great. Compared to other areas in in Lisbon, this is definitely more happening. Although, compared to other capital cities in Europe, it doesn'toffer much.
It's all here. The party area of Lisbon, this one thrives all days of the week. Evenings, especially, are a great time to be here.
Center. This is the center of Lisbon with many great shops, a lot of restaurants, bars, nightlife etc. Sadly, there is also som drug dealer bothering you.

For locals and tourists alike. There is something about Chiado that makes it so charming and inviting at any time of the day. It may get a little crowded, especially during December or summer holidays, but it still worth a visit (and not a short one). Despite all the tourists, there are good choices of restaurants and cafes that are not traps, unlike the Rossio/Baixa area which is filled with the infamous "tourist traps". Just make sure you check reviews before going. Locals can be seen hanging in the neighborhood too. Overall, as far as what it has to offer, it is a great area to explore and it will probably leave you wanting to go back again and again.Tips: don't miss out on Gelado Santini (it's worth it even if there's a line, which is common during summer) and for dining try Sacramento, which also has a good lunch buffet.
A shopping and eating district. Worth visiting on your way through to Barrio Alto. However, as an area in its own right....it's worth an hour or two.
Busy. Best part of the city for expensive shopping,many tourists,much uphill walking,nice restaurants,take a tuk-tuk to the top.great fun
Shopping Lisbon Style. Bustling shopping area mixed with residential neighborhood. A great place to see and be seen. No bargains but plenty of beautiful side streets, cafés, and tiny shops.
we lived there. our rented flat was in the neighbourhood. it was great. center of the city, load but bearable, lots of people, locals and turists, hills, cafes bars - you have everything there

Top shops..... Love this place.
Best designer shops... Lost of choices...... Lost if variety....
Then there is little restaurantes , cafés , pastelarias..... That you can have your drink, eat good abdul tradicional food....
In the center of Lisbon what else one can ask for!!!

My favorite area to spend my weekend. This classic and centrally located area is a place to be on a sunny day or during the weekend. It has all kinds of activities to offer. If you like shopping, eating at great restaurants, sipping good coffee or simply walking around, this is definitely a unique place to use your precious time. I always walk from home to this area whenever I have a free time and I always find a cool thing to do.
makes you feel happy. atmosphere is relaxing, restaurants great, makes you feel happy..enjoyed walking around, but even more driving in legendary small yellow tram

Nice area for a walk, not many unique shops. This is a nice area to take a walk and grab some lunch. The pedestrian streets are nice although the selection of shops is limited to some tacky souvenir shops. Save your money if you are looking for a souvenir t shirt and head to Colombo Mall where you can walk to the official Benfica Merchandise store and find something of higher quality.

Old area of town. First, it seems there is some confusion about Chiado. This is a shopping and intellectual part of Lisbon. Located on the hill side, just below Bairrio Alto (on top of the hill) and Restadaures (in the hollow where the city squares are).This is one heart of the city. It is a shopping district with fine examples of typical Portuguese architecture. Many famous country scholars were born in this area, which is part of downtown Lisbon.

The actual heart of the city. We stayed in the city for 3 nights and every night we ended up spending in chiado. Its very lively and you would see the entire city in this location, specially on weekends. Definitely a must see and walk from Chiado to Bairo alto where the whole city parties
Very nice to stroll around and discover details about Lisbon. Full of nice little cafés, nice boutiques. Very lively!Look for the Santini ice cream place and order the strawberry one!

Wander the streets and defintely take the tram. The old part of Lisbon a walk around here,a coffee stop or lunch and a tram ride through the narrow streets cannot be missed. Full of life, many delightful buildings.

A place not to be missed. This area is the very heart of Lisbon down-town and should not be missed by anyone visiting Lisbon. The core of Lisbon social life since the second half of XIX century, it decayed after the big fire that destroyed a great part of this neighbourhood in 1988. Restored according a plan designed by the architecture Pritzker price winner Portuguese architect Siza Vieira, it became slowly to revitalize, becoming nowadays one of the most exciting and vivid areas of Lisbon. There you can find museums, restaurants, cafes, theatres, opera, hotels and high standard shops. Nice to walk, take a coffee, observe the charming built environment, mingle with a cosmopolitan flow of people, you shall not to miss it!
Shop and People Watch. A great place to walk around with plenty of very good shops and cafes and restaurants. Can very easily spend half a day here.
Great neighborhood!. This is like Lisbon's Soho area. Lots of shops, great restaurants and great museums. We went here several times during our trip to just hang out and people watch.

One 'must visit' in Lisbon. Great area, with nice shops in old buildings. I recommend walking up the hill from Baixa, starting where the old steel elevator is located. The area has a very nice feel to it and a good mix of shops, restaurants and cafes.

A good place for people watching. Chiado is the heart of real Lisbon. We lived here for almost 6 years and when we returned this year after selling our apartment 2 years ago, we found it still a charming place to be. Eat ice cream at Santin's. Sit next to Mr. Pesoa's statue and drink a Bica, watch the musicians, the mimes, the shoppers, the Romas and enjoy Lisbon, beautiful city.

Wonderful area to explore. The mix between locals and tourists, the variety of services, shops and restaurants is great. Great place to work around and explore the new infused with the old. Definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon.

Nice touristic area. Easy to get into by metro (the the escalators of the subway station Baixa-Chiado will take you directly there) well connected also by common public transports, it is a nice area full of restaurants, bakeries and boutiques. Depart from the square many small alleys in which is fun to find food or pub or local fado where to spend the evening and the night. There is also the stop for famous number "28". I suggest you to take it on late evening, it will be an amazing trip up and down the hill much better than any rollercoaster.

Beautiful Area of the City. One of the more hip areas of Lisbon. This is where you'll see street style. As well as beautiful churches and an open area. Wonderful boutiques, cafes, or restaurants. Not to be missed.

Touristy. This place had lots of shops and places to eat ..restaurants and cafes. It had a nice atmosphere and is one of the prettier areas of Lisbon. We were just walking past here. It was very busy. Beware as there are pickpockets here . so look after your purses and belongings .

Not enough shopping. Chiado is a nice area covering a few short streets and holding shops as Massimo Dutti or a beautifully located Tous, some local brands of fashion, shoes, nice jewelry, perfumeries and the great local small shop selling hand made gloves.There is also a small mall, not very attractive in terms of brand mix or appearance.Some more and better quality shops would have improved the shopping experience.A good note for the many restaurants and cafes around, among which the famous A Brasileira Cafe.

Charming part of the city. Lovely place to roam around and enjoy all it has to offer . Great also for people watching and best enjoyed on foot . Nice area to sit and relax after some walking and enjoy a coffee - but keep a close eye on your bag and wallet as in all central areas of Lisbon !! It is a lovely city to explore but full of people begging and sleeping rough which is a bit uncomfortable .

Cosy. One of the main squares in Lisbon. We've been here a few times because it's so central. Be aware of metro scammers in this region (metro stops Restauradores and Baixa Chiado): they'll approach you (sometimes after helping you out recharging your metro ticket) and say that "they're 3 euros short" to buy their own metro ticket. It's just a more modern way of street begging. They won't buy a ticket, they just want to rip off people a few euros at a time.
Shopping and more shopping!. Great area to walk around, window shop, go in to the shops and catch a bite to eat! Very picturesque and quaint.

Do not miss. This is a fun part of the city to walk around. The streets are full with people with great atmosphere and this is before mentioning all the great shopping, coffee places and restuarnts. Do not miss this part of the city (Comfortable shoes advised)

good for shopping. a nice area to walk around in, full of well known brands and great as a shopping district. Within walking distance of the Bairro and other cool restaurants, bars and roadside cafes.
Charming. Charming place, specially if you have the right guide (like Taylor from Oasis hostel). Local people is very interesting and there are many nonturistic places to enjoy.

Wonderful shopping district. Great distinctive shops.Many been there for years.Oldest book store in Europe.Tiny shop which sells only glovesGreat old cafes with seating on the street.Come fast before replaced by chain stores
fashion. maybe the most fashion place in Lisboa. Go there with time sit down on a chair outside Café Brasileira and see the people going and going, all kind of people
Nice area. Chiado is a lovely area which is great for rambling around. There are many hills and lots to explore. Lovely architecture and good for shopping too.

wonderful walk. Beautiful old buildings mixed with new and contemporary. I recommend you walk and take advantage of all the little Pastelarias tucked away down the old streets. Lots of old boarded up places , but makes it quaint , the architecture very romantic and also a bit gothic. Some great shops too :) If you get worn out , take a tram ..ding ding.

People Watching. During warmer days I can imagine sitting outside with a coffee and a pastel de nata watching the world go by but unfortunately when there is a "refreshing" wind, the best place to view anything is from the comfort of being inside one of the excellent coffee house surrounding the square.
spending a nice time. A complete different area as Alfama but worth while indeed. Nice shops, restaurants and bars. everywere friendly people.
One from 7 historical Lisbon districts. Ideal for walking with many small shops, and interesting buildings. It is worth to visit and to see.
Busy shopping and restaurant area.. Hilly area where shops and restaurants are a little pricier. Go off the main streets to explore. Try the Trinidad restaurant.

Great place in Lisbon. Chiado and Bairro Alto are my favorite places in Lisbon. Chiado is a beautiful place, and everyone who visits the city should walk around its streets. Nice place for shopping also.
Great area for eating and shopping. A great area in Lisbon to look for a nice restaurant and have a great meal, and also for shopping. Nice atmosphere and always lots of people.

Nice square. Not sure why this an attraction as it is just a square you walk through on the way to the bar area. There are a number of nice shops in the area and when we were there they had some great sales on.

Posh shopping & nice eateries. Lots if designer shops and boutiques, on a steep incline and cobbled so don't wear stilettos! Some very nice places to eat up here, ice cream from Santini's is a must. Immaculately clean streets and lots of street entertainers around.
brilliant shopping!. The best in shopping in Lisbon. Loved the little boutiques and cute eateries with locals...A must visit!
Fantastic. Great area downtown, with a lot of stores, nice restaurants (especially in the upper area), beautiful elevator and street cars.
Worth the visit. Really nice outdoor shopping area with loads of good shops and eateries. Great for a full day just strolling around and wonderful exercise as it is fairly hilly!!

NICE ARTCHITECTURE GOOD SHOPPING. Nice compact area but not a lot local flavour. Some pressure from waiters to come into restuarants and several beggars detract from the area. The streets running down to the river have a good range of shops

The nicest area of Lisbon. Full of restaurants, cafes, bakeries and shops - place to have a good time with family and friends. Well communicated with underground, tram (including the famous "28") and taxis. If you want to enjoy peace and quite this is NOT the place to be ... Crawded, with a lots of tourists but you may find small places where local people spend lazy time drinking coffee and eating fantastic sweets.

Very Nice Area. Every day we had to go to Chiado. There are fine restaurants with Fado live performance (I personally enjoyed). Very nice bakeries for the breakfast yummy bakeries. Shopping also & you can take the tram from there & explore the city. A must visit!

Very pleasant area to stroll around..... If you are looking for a pleasant historic area to roam around, with plenty of shops and cafes (Which is flat as well) then this is it.A grid of white marble(like) streets this area has plenty of locally run eateries / souvenir shops / curiosity shops and yet doesn't feel like a tourist area as there are many local shops and legions of locals using them.Downsides ? Maybe it was simply because we visited between Christmas and New Year but the waste bins were overflowing. Otherwise a lovely area to roam around and relax.
Walking and shopping. Chiado is a nice area of Lisbon, perfect for doing some shopping. Easy to get around, flat area and lots of cafés and shops.

Charming shopping. This area of the city is one of the most beautiful shopping areas I visited in the world.Here you'll find the big brands and the typical cafés, or small shops full of history and charm.
You must go!. If you have chosed Lisbon for your hollidays, you must go to the Chiado area, it's really nice! You may walk around and take a sit in a coffe and taste the snacks, excellent!

Feel local at Chiado. The atmosphere of the area is magic. If you can, take one of the trams up to A Brasileira, a delicious cafe with the statue of Fernando Pessoa in front of it. Just enjoy the area.
Fado in Chiado. If you have not been and don't know anything about it. This is the place to go. Well done. One hour. Talented performers. inexpensive

Loved Chiado.... Wonderful visit. Great place to stroll or sit at an outdoor cafe and people watch. Shopping, entertainment, Chiado has it all. We dined at numerous restaurants in this area of Lisbon, and then hit the wine bars until they closed pretty much each night of our stay. The local shop keepers and residents were all very helpful with directions or questions.

Lovely Area. Great area to stay! Easy to travel to and from the airport by bus or metro. Easy walking distance to the main shopping area, Justa Lift, tour buses and restaurants. Would stay here again the next time I am in Lisbon.

Chiado has everything that is good. The Chiado is the fashion district of Lisbon where you will find boutique hotels, the best spots to drink coffee at a neighborhood famous pastry, a drink, dinner or snack with very variable and see where alternative and vintage stores prices.

The nightlife is worth a second visit. We went during the day and it was sleepy and quiet. Reading that it came alive at night we made the journey up the hill for a second try. Don't miss the fun. We caught some great live music for the price of a drink, and even tore up the rug a bit.
Good Walk. Very nice and fashion neighborhood. There you can have a very nice Portuguese coffee "bisca" and visit very nice shops.

Great Neighborhood to Chill And People Watch. Chiado can be reached by Metro or foot. There is also the Elevador De Santa Justa nearby. The area has a real buzz about it and at night there are street entertainers and plenty of cafes to grab an outside table to take it all in. As we wandered around Lisbon we often ended up here just to have a drink and watch all of the interesting people passing by. This area is not to be missed if you are in Lisbon.

A place to browse. Shops, places to eat people watch.It's all here.Guys hawking sunglasses a guy playing an accordion with a pet dog and high end stores mixed in with T shirt shops.What I don't get is that in NYC you can buy 3 t shirts for $9.99 yet in Lisbon a much less expensive town even the made in China tees are 9.90 Euros.Anyway who cares , drink wine eat & laugh
Beautiful. This is a really beautiful area, it lights up at night so making anytime a worth while visit. Lovely range of shops surrounding the area to wind away the hours

Culture and bohemia. It's a cultural and bohemian area from Lisbon.It's a city's vibrant nightlife .Much of the area was destroyed in a fire in 1988, but now there are elegantes brands, sophisticated theaters, bookshops, cafes, jewelry shops, etc

What a lovely quarter.. This is an absolutely lovely quarter.It is well worth the steep walk up Rua Garrett.The place is packed with cafés, restaurants, shops and offers a very touristic experience – both day and night.The place was almost burnt to the ground in the 1988 horrible fire, but thankfully, it was restored to its previous beauty.Don't miss the two beautiful churches, facing eachotherm in Largo do Chiado.
Real Lisbon downtown. I lived in Lisbon many years and returned with a group of friends to spend some vacation days. Chiado for us is the place to be from restaurants to nightlife.

Uptown Charm. This is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Lisbon..close to a Metro, full of interesting shops and restaurants. And spectacular views! Just around the corner north is the Principe Real park and the Botanic Garden, and west is the Pharmacy Museum and restaurant. Don't miss this in your visit to Lisbon.
Lively interesting area. Plenty of bars and restaurants, beautiful church and only a short walk form the main square and Barrio Alta

so so. Storied place but overrated.
My wife enjoyed the shops. I enjoyed the atmosphere.
Worth going once at least

Fresh clean and airy, but very small.. This may be one of the smallest shopping malls you will ever encounter. But it is very busy and active. I found the street side shopping much more enjoyable. But, check it out if you are in the area.
Lisbon's Heart. Lisbon best place to go shopping, walk, have a coffee or a meal. It's full of trendy places and cosmopolitan people.

Trendy place.... Its a trendy place nearby arts schools, models agencies, theaters, street artists and a lot of cafés. Visit S. Carlos Theater, enjoy a coffee (expensive one) at the terrace of the Hotel Chiado where you can enjoy a great view of Lisbon and Castelo S. Jorge. Feel the place just walking and seating the cafes promenades.

Stay In This Part of Town!. We just arrived home from 15 days in Portugal, 4 discovering Lisbon itself. It is an interesting, historical, amazing & delicious place. The locals are very friendly, helpful and English is widely spoken.Tips: stay in Chiado or one of the other old parts of town. The streets are unique and great to explore. Eat where the locals eat. The food is good & the price is great. Be prepared to walk up and down hills and steps. Wear comfortable shoes as the streets and pavements are cobbled. You will have a great time exploring this historic area and city.

Lively downtown area.. There always seems to be something going on near the Baixa-chiado metro from street dance, human statues, political demonstrations, student pranks for freshers' week even a man making grasshoppers and scorpions from plaited wheat stalks. There pavement cafes for people watching.The shopping streets have high street names like Zara and Benneton as well as upmarket individual boutiques.

Good shopping opportunities (for adults). It's definitely lively (more touristed/international than local), and there's a lot of shopping opportunities, for those who like that, with cafés that offers a nice break. Note it's not particulary interesting for young children, and for people, who aren't in to shopping, also there's no shopping opportunities if you like to buy something for your young ones (e.g. toy cars), in which case you'll have to go to El Corte Inglés. It's easy to get there with the Metro.

If staying in Lisbon, this is the neighborhood. This is one of the flattest areas of Lisbon. Everything you could need within. Great public transportation. Dining and drinking establishments. Lots of outdoor venues. Beautiful square on the waterfront. We loved it :)
Must to see. Very nice neighbor, you can easily go by metro and has a lot too see and explorer, good for a walking shopping and eating
Nice site. Very interesting and a must see site. I had the greatest time there and I wish I could be back there soon.
The place to stay!. In the middle of pedestrian streets, shops and restaurants all around- just loved the location! I'll be back soon I hope!
Personality!. Spend some time here, eat a meal and you will see. Like Lisbon in general, this neighborhood has great ambience and personality.

Fun Place to Explore. I loved Chaido...just very lively, a lot of people, and fun to just walk around, eat, and shop. Glad my husband and I decided to spend time here during our short visit to Lisbon.

Chiado area adjacent to the Tagus. Being Irish,we called to Hennessys Bar on the Sunday afternoon to watch the All Ireland hurling final. Great atmosphere there and is a good size bar with v good Guinness. Not there any night but believe they have entertainment at weekends.

A must for first time visitors. The relatively small neighborhood / shopping district of Chiado are home to many well-known restaurants, bars and cafés as well as shops. The buildings and streets are very beautiful and if you walk a few meters away from the main street it is tranquil and full of gems.
Fun at night, next to Barrio Alto. Big open Squares with outdoor cafes, people watching and street performers. Have a drink here after dinner in the Barrio Alto.
lively. It`s a very lively area, with things always happening. you have the Elevator near and a shopping centre as well. Loads of restaurants to choose.
Lovely area. Very nice area to wander through in the evening watching the street entertainers. Lots of nice restaurants.

Lovely Place / Great fun!. The place for fun! In front of A Brasiliera bar, just across from Baixa-Chiado metro station every evening there is a freelance band entertaining tourists. People mingle and dance on the street creating a great feeling of freedom and joy. There lots of artist offering beatiful and good priced souvenirs."A Brasileira" has been a "posh" destination for going out for almost a century and offers probably the cheapest coffee or beer in town - 0.7 euro, namely 1.8 euro for beers. Be carefull though, these are the prices at the counter, there is a different price for ordering @ the tables inside & another for the "esplanada" (street bar).

Great area!. This area was just up the street from our hotel and we walked around at night and during the day with no problems. There are a lot of restaurants and bars around and we stopped off our first night in a bar close by that had live entertainment. We had a blast!! I hope one day we can revisit Lisbon as I find its such a beautiful interesting place!

Lisboa at its best!. The Chiado area is one of the most beautiful parts of Lisbon's old downtown area. Many luxury shops, excelente restaurants, bars, a lively night scene and the place for you to enjoy "Fado" (portuguese music).

Chiado - Fabulous area in Lisbon. The Chiado area of Lisbon is historic and has wonderful restaurants and sites. We stayed in the Teatro B&B, absolutely a terrific hotel. Located in the Chiado, we could walk easily to adjoining central areas, numerous restaurants, historic sites, the lively Baixa Chiado square and subway station. The Chiado is just a terrific central area in Lisbon to explore.
Great neighborhood. Real feeling of Lisbon, get lost in the narrow streets of this great part of town!! Experience the local life

Trendy heart of lisbon. Close to the center of the old town (Baixa) chiado is nowadays the heart of Lisbon regarding restaurants, and young people nightlife. During the day it deserves a full visit, getting lost and descovering fascinatings gems in every other street. When the night comes, specially at the weekend, it turns into one of the top destinations for people wanting to party. If you don't like "drinking crowds" and "littered streets" avoid it after midnight.

Kind of high end. Fancier part of Lisbon, with some fancy shops and cafes, another contribution to a great charm that Lisbon spreads around. If you have couple of days in Lisbon, surely you will come to Chiado several times and not only once.

Lisbon at its best. If you are visiting Lisbon this is a place you have to walk around in. Just stroll the streets, admire the architecture and the flavor of the real Lisbon. The center of this is Praça cameos and then head down the pedestrian street to the FNAC bookstore at the end of the road. The Teatro San Carlos is close by, a real gem of a theatre. Numerous shops and eating places around here.
walking around. i love to walk around this area. its big and very nice. buy some pastries sit watch people around you. great weather. lovely place for shopping.

Wonderful Home Base while in Lisbon!. We were fortunate to find an apartment on the Praça Luis de Camões and what a place! Beautiful, people watching square in front of us and right in the middle of everything! The tr.28 runs right by, metro station 1-2 blocks away and every type of resturant you can think of within a few blocks walk. Defintely right in the center of everything and a fantastic area to see the city from!

Brentwood Terry. The apartment was beautiful & the staff were truly amazing & made some great suggestions. Went to a Fado recital at the museum followed by superb tapas @ tagide, which we can all highly recommend. will definitely come back to this delightful boutique hotel.

standard fancy shopping district. if you like shopping at fancy stores that you can find in most major cities then you'll like this neighborhood. there's nothing particularly wrong with it but I prefer the more down to earth neighborhood. also be prepared for a fairly steep hill. the partying is really in the neighborhood next door, barrio alto.

Shopping Expedition. While my husband was presenting his paper at a conference, I hopped on the Metro and went souvenir shopping in Chiado. The Metro is safe and cheap so don't be afraid to use it. Whatever you are looking for, you can find it in Chiado. Rolex? There is a store. Reasonable souvenirs. Yup. I also found two stores selling handmade items from Portugal and one store that stocks items made from cork. It was just fun to wander around the little side streets. On Sunday, there was a craft market down by the river.
Great little shopping area. very nice shopping, street performers, very nice area just to walk around in closeby to main squares.

Place to go for shopping, eating and hanging out.. Really nice shopping and hanging out arena - nice crowd and good shopping - lots of good places to eat at. We were there for 4-5 hours and could have spent more time.
Great spot to shop and eat in the surrounding areas.. Chiado is a scaled down version of our shopping centers. High fashion small stores. Good for International wear.

The hot spot of Lisboa.. This is a scene of great beauty ond much activity. The bar La Brasileira is a classic and the statues of Fernando Pessoa and António Ribeira add to the atmosphere. Constant activity and many shopping opportunities.
Lively all night long. We rented an apartment here. It is partying until 4 am. Nice diversity and shops with easy public transport access. The real Lisbon with a very busy center square

My favourite place. I love to walk in chiado, it's a beautiful area to discover by foot. It has beautiful buildings with pombaline architecture . You will find many shops , to buy clothes, shoes ,and many souvenir shops, try to avoid the Indian shops , they sell all the same things. Try to go to traditional shops, I like the shop " vida Portuguesa " in anchieta street. Take care of your belongings wen you walk. Enjoy chiado
Chiado's Café Brasileira. Chiado's Café Brasileira is a must to see the Art Nouveau decorations, street performers and the ruins of Igreja do Carmo demolished to a ruin in the 1755 Earthquake.

Shopping hot spot. So many shoes, so little time. Shop til you drop then head for a glass of bubbly!
So many shoes, so little time. Shop til you drop then head for a glass of bubbly!
Very charming. Very charming quarter, worth a stroll to taste and appreciate one of the most lively place place in town
Very Fun Night. Very fun night with the bars and all of the people hanging out in this neighborhood. I went with a bar crawl and it was helpful to be with someone who knew which places were good.
Chiado and Bexia. Great shopping and dining area. We walked quite a lot in this area and it has some very nice shops and quite a few of the restaurants with outdoor terraces have wifi.
Busy and chic. Great for a mooch day and night, with local and global stores, and great bars in the evening. Best to try to hold off nail going out nail later, when everything really comes alive.

Nice but going down hill. Again, I love Lisbon, but was disappointed to see the effects of the economic downturn around the city. Lots of places are boarded up, under construction, covered with scaffolding or surrounded by dirt bags with dogs, dreads and drugs for sale. That gets old pretty fast... so sad because it's such a great city!

Great neighborhood to explore. Start with tram 28 to get oriented then hop off and start walking! There are lovely squares, the Carmo ruins are interesting, cocktails on the roof bar at hotel bizarro alta provide great views and people watching!

Soho of Lisbon. This district is small but well located between the Bairo Alto
and the Baixa (commercial district) Top cafes, first class
restaurants, hotels,designer shops, historical sites, theaters, and
good transportation. This his the chic part of town, always was.
Extremely active at night , Free concerts in the Largo do Sao Carlos, from late June to late July.

Nice chill place. This place is filled with shops and restaurants. If you just want to lounge, shop and have a good al fresco meal. Chiado is a good place to go and visit. Service hear was top notch as waiters are used to foreigners so English was not a problem at all for them.

Chillen. What a great place to relax outside at a cafe or restaurant drinking latte or a glass of wine depending on the time of day. There is always entertainment on the street or great people watching. P.S. awsome shopping

great fun place. lots of stores, people from around the world,artist painting on benches on plazas is summer so everyone is out enjoying the sunny days,great food and shopping time i go everyday for coffe or just to look around
A pleasant shopping area connecting.... Bairro Alto and Baixa districts. Try the Rick Steves guide walking tour for a map and a listing of the sights in the area.

fun shopping and cafe culture. fun to walk around - cafes on the whole were very touristy and service can be somewhat "french". Great icecream shops - Santini and Amorino. Good shopping - give the big brands a miss and scout around for Portuguese shoes, bags, gloves and clothes, linen - really good quality and good prices too; Look for the good Portuguese crafts shops rather than made in china two dollar shops - they are worth it, even if prices are set for tourists. Great wine and cheese around too, and naturally the bread if really great!
Fun nightlife and eateries. Lots of activity - many charming and funky restaurants to choose from. Seems to be a lot with music which is fun.
buzz. chiado has every thing shops cafes restaurants win bars street performers even people selling drugs the place really has a buzz about it well worth a visit.

Wish we had had more time to explore this neighborhood. The only time we found ourselves in the heart of Chiado, it happened purely by mistake. We got on the Tram 28 thinking it was going to take us up the hill to the heart of Alfama, which is where we were staying, as it always did. But the Tram we got on was some sort of alternate route for the weekend, I guess, because it took some roundabout turn, and ended at Praca Luis Camoes, the heart of Chiado, but nowhere near where we wanted to go.I calmly took out my map and traced the way back to the tram stop, and we began walking. But as walked, we saw a number of lovely shops, and found ourselves stopping at more than one. It was our last day in Lisbon, so we didn't have a chance to come back and explore Chiado further, but if we had had time, we surely would've planned to return.

Night & Day. Chiado has his own life inside Lisbon city. You will find lovely restaurants, hostels, hotels with amazing charm. During night you will find lots of bars open late, besides some gourmet shops or wine bars, where you can delight with the portuguese wines. Lots of action in the street with performers.

City old areas renewed. The ambient is very friendly with nice shops in the old buildings, and with the street performers.You can see the old Lisbon architecture and visit the café where Fernando Pessoa, an estimed writer, spent its time.
Great atmosphere. Loved the atmosphere, felt like being in Covent Garden in London or Soho Mahattan. Great shops, and close to Bairro Alto for restaurants and bars. Rossio good for entertainment.

A Central Hub. Chiado metro is next door to the Cafe Brasiliana, one of the city's oldest and most popular. It is also on the route of the city's most scenic tram 28 and has lots of interesting shops, bars and restaurants. Many of the shops are too posh to put price stickers on the merchandise, but this is by no means as snooty an area as it would be in another city.

Book shop is good.. Bertrand bookshop is very old and fabulous to wander through; if you love books that is.Brasileiria coffee shop is just OK...over rated, with lots of street activity, buskers etc outside.The two churches nearby are very beautiful and worth a visit.
Everything in one spot. We loved this area of Lisbon. Lots of people, lots of noise, lots of everything. The squares are surrounded with shops and eating places.

Nice place for a stroll at night. It was a pleasant walk around there, with beautiful fountains and lights, choice of bars, some with live music going on. Worth going for at least a little half hour to get the feel. Beware of the guys selling drugs, though, if you have kids but other than that, just say no and they leave you in peace.

fun for night walking, food generally unimaginative. Lots of fun sights, bars, sidewalk cafe's, busy at night. Nice, but the food is overwhelmingly similar from sidewalk restaurant to sidewalk restaurant. Go a little further uphill to Alto Bairrio and you'll find better prepared and selection of food in quieter alleys.

U Chiada. Plenty of nightlife and restaurants. We went (twice) to U Chiada the Trendy Bar and Restaurant. Don't be put off by its name! The food and service are excellent. We had their set menu of 5 courses (38 Euros) which is a 'surprise' and changes each night. Each course was explained and beautifully presented. This place reopened in September 2012 and is trying to build up business. If you are Chiado give it a try.

In LOVE with this district!. So you want to feel as if you live in Lisbon, this might just do the trick. The shopping around the streets is great and the coffee shops around Hotel Borges are very charming and reminiscent of the old days of Lisbon. There is usually music in the air in the streets during the day while the bars in the area can have fado at night. Tram 28 will get to this area as well as the metro has a stop that will pop you right into the middle of all the happenings.
Great shopping area with beautiful buildings around. Hermes starts off from the station at Baixa-Chiado and it is a Champs de Elysees-Lisbon style in a cozy beautiful neighborhood.

Chiado a best part of Lisbon to live. Many streets in Chiado are pedestrian with a lot's of shops and a restaurants. It is situated on a beggining of a hill of Bairro Alto from the central part of Baixa. Charming, original and safe part of the city with everything you need a foot away.
Fashion. I would love to live here. In the downtown, with all essential services, night life (near to Bairro Alto), beautiful and fashionable people

Lots to do and see. This district is beautiful and has lots of trendy restaurants and shops. People are always out and about, especially fun to walk around at night. Feels very safe. You can take the number 28 tram, which is an adventure all it's own! Just don't stay in this district if you want to sleep at night and are not used to noise. We loved being in the centre of the action, but jet-lagged as we were it was not possible to get to sleep until well after 4am. I would look into the proximity of bars (good luck, they are everywhere) if you are worried about your beauty sleep and planning to stay in this district.

Great Views of the City. We visited Chiado several times during our stay in Lisbon. You can go by lift using the elevator Santa Justa or the vernicular railway and they frequently are busy. You can also walk up if you are fit. There are lots of interesting shops and restaurants at the top but our favourite area was the lookout locally called the Boulevard. There you will find a small park overlooking the Baixa and the harbour with an outdoor cafe where you can get a drink and enjoy the view. The night lights are quite pretty.
The most lively area in Lisbon. The greatest place in Lisbon to be located. Very close to a lot of restaurants, shops and touristic places

Great both during the day and at night. The "shopping" district is not only about shopping. There a few nice places to visit and you can spend a whole day strolling among the key sites in the place. The shops are of course a popular destination for a lot of people in the streets, but equally busy are the local restaurants. The place is very ease to get as it's reachable by car/bus/trams/trains and subway.

Shopping experience and great city walk. A great place to shop for souveniors that hardly found elsewhere along the way to the city centre. Dont forget to try the special "white & sweet" cookies "indegenous" to Portugese, although it was too sweet for me, but not more compare to "baklava" from Turkish. Check out the arts and materials on their building, truthly amazing feel of being in Portugal.
Chic cafes and shopping. Lively neighbourhood full of trendy cafes and restaurants and some of the best shops in Lisbon.In particular,good shoe shops with amazingly low prices by European standards.
Fun area. Chia do is a fun and historic area. There is a church on the square that is quit nice. Lots of shopping and little cafes. Easy to get to by metro.

City center. Chiado is one of the most important areas in Lisbon and it's different than the old Bairro Alto (old city). It gives you a flavour of Lisbon fashionly different and you may see the real inhabitants of Lisbon.
Lots of character and hustle bustle. Went there on the last day. Tram journey from Castle Jorg was memorable. Great views into the city. Good cafes, shopping and busking.
Fun and festive!. While not exactly the place to go when looking for the history of the city, it is definitely worth a visit to see the relaxed and fun part of Lisbon.

Well worth a visit. Its a great place to wander through the very narrow cobbled streets - so really good restaurants and small local bars. Its a very different part of Lisbon and one worth experiencing. There are plenty of street artists on the main square... Enjoy the athmosphere : )

Chiado. Chiado is one of the most iconic and traditional neighborhoods of Lisbon.
It has an incredible romanticism, obligatory passage point too, With famous shops, restaurants, cafe, street performers;
a v good upmarket.... Chiado is the place where u can get all the designer n top branded garments.its an expensive upmarket.

Plenty to see & do. Clean , tidy. Plenty of shops / cafes / restaurants. Great for pic taking. Arrive to the area via tram/bus or metro if unable to walk.
Would recommend a visit.
Great shopping and walking area. If you want to buy some small things, this is the best place and also you can try to get some discounts as well ;)

atmospheric. A lovely area to walk around, day or night. The great thing about this area and Lisbon in general is that it's so safe. People don't bother you and you can just wander around and explore to your heart's content. Lovely cafes and shops, gives a good idea of what Lisbon is all about
Interesting place to walk around. Just wander the old streets and enjoy the shops, restaurants, and sites. Gives a better sense of old Lisbon than either Baixa or Bairro Alto.

The place to walk. This area of town is a must for travelers. It's the place where people get together for a coffee or a beer. Also a place full of small restaurants and some shops. There is a subway station right at it. A nice place to start a walk.

Great outdoor shopping area. I love Chiado not only for its stores, but also for the street environment and coffee shops. A Brasileira is always a favorite, despite its tourist high prices. It is also a perfect place to find a nice restaurant and have a meal or drinks to have a rest after climbing all those lisboeta slopes!

Great shopping district and great restaurants. This is a part of Lisbon that offers a lot. Great shops, restaurants, museums. One can easily lose the track of time there. Some of the best restaurants and cafes are there.
walk arround and discover. Fantastic unique shops and stuff to buy. Small cafes and restaurantes. Go to bairro alto and principe real, just walking.

Great Shopping District. Loved this area. In the heart of the old part of the city. This is THE AREA to stay in Lisbon. I described this old part of Lisbon to be similar to San Francisco, CA. Very hilly...leave your high heels at home and bring really comfortable shoes to climb these steep hills.

wonderful place for shopping and refreshments. good area for shopping, and having refreshments in cafes. you can go museums within area and access to riverside by walk.
Also, there are plenty of restrauants near Chiado; you can go one of them for the dinner or lunch

Good to explore... visited during the day...wide range of stores catering to different budgets...they had great offers at many stores during my visit..many options for food also...its close to lot of transportation options...i liked the different walkway patterns...and dont miss the statue man (if he's still around)..

Great for a shopaholic like me!. I love to shop. Here you will find stores like Zara, G Star, Berksha, Blanco, Benneton etc. It's a wide flat area with a mall and it's surrounded by places to eat and drink.

the place to be. it seems to be the heart of Lisbon: there is something happening there every moment of the day. you can find shopping in great international shops or small lical brands, you can go from there wherever you want to visit or you can simply stay and watch hirryingpeople all around, tourists or locals. you can see policemen or homeless people, you can see beautifullydressed ladies or rebel teenagers.when you don't know what to doin lisbon, g there and you find the answer

Great shopping, food and places to visit. I work here, and I love it everyday ! Its a very cool place to visit for shopping, to eat, to visit museums or churches. There are always lots of tourists, but also students and business suits. Its also very close to Bairro Alto so you can drop by if not to tired. Lots of transportation : bus, tram and metro.Dont miss it !
The place to be. Chiado is a must-see, especially for the nightlife. Famous Fado houses, restaurants and bars. Live music. Get lost there and enjoy it.

just one hour walk, no more. Augusto street, is much better to wonder around, than Chiado.... but you "may" find a good restaurant to have a meal. If you missed going there, you did Not miss a lot, because most of the areas down town are the same. the brand name shops are present in any mall ( even together in one place ). Our experience with the area was Not impressing. You can see and judge yourself. Good luck.

Beautiful!. A nice place in the historical centr of Lisbon. A good stroll. Go to the A Brasileira, to have coffee and "pastelinhos" and "chat" with Fernando Pessoa, in bronze. If you like shopping, there are all kinds of places you can shop till you drop. Don't miss it.
Beautiful area with good shopping. As the title says; beautiful area with good shopping. Pretty buildings, some of the known brands and also some more exclusive.
Vibrant. One of the most vibrant places in the city. Traditional stores mix with modern trends, maintaining the typical trace of that side of town... Just love it!

Stay in this area. Ended up staying in an apartment in Chiado and so glad we did. Perfect location for shops and walking. Very central and full of character. Don't stay north of rossio station unless you want sterile atmosphere.
Brilliant part of city. The Chiado is a beautiful part of Lisbon, the Opera House, shops/galleries and bars all make this a must see on any trip to Lisbon.
a flavour of Lissabon. Not a fancy neighbourhood, but very authentic. It is nice for a stroll around and some window shopping. Don't forget to look for a shop with vintage port wines!
Central Lisbon. This one you shouldn´t miss, wether you are looking to shop, sightseeing or just taking a walk this one is a must in Lisbon!
Interesting shopping district. I went her as recommended by rough guide for some quirky shops and wasn't disappointed. Good to wander around if you have seen the other sites.

A great walk. Many interesting areas, soem shops that have deep history and plenty to explore - whether it be squares, churches or shops - all are worthwhile and must be sen as part of a visit to Lisbon
Great location. I walked around and Chiado is a very nice place to do so. Good museums and streets to know the new and old Portuguese culture.
Attractive small shopping streets, shops, galleries etc. Pleasant part of old town. civilised well kept, narrow streets, good shops and galleries, and small squares with cafes etc.

Lisbon is a must!. Nice neighborhood to walk around, beautiful sightseeing, Good restaurants, shops, very beautifgood public transportationGood restaurants, shops, very beautiful with old buildings, very nice people everyhwere
Shopping. Lovely to shop up here, quality but pricey. You pay for the experience but it is worth it to find that special thing.

Our apartment in Chiado. We loved this neighborhood ... although very busy late into the night. Make sure your lodging has closed windows to block out the noise. Close to everything you will need - lots of locals.
Tons of Shops! Great Soup!. Wander the streets and stop anywhere for a coffee, gelato or a soup. Try the Caldo Verde where ever you can. It's a traditional Portugese soup that they serve everywhere.
Weekened in Lisbon. Where else to go to eat? Hundreds of restaurants and wine bars. Just go. Look around and get a seat somewhere!! iTS ALL GOOD!

Fascinating and tricky!. Well we walked around the area and it was fascinating but we did get lost despite trying to follow a guided walk...doesn't matter though cos you're not far from anywhere and you can always hop on a tram...
Shopping street!. The mall and the street are a great point for shopping. A variety of labels in the heart of Lisbon. Cafes and various happenings are contributing to a very relaxed atmosphere!!

nice high street for fashion shopping. Its a nice place to wander around for a typical European city center high street feel, but it lacks much interestingness unlike Rome or say Vaci Utca in Budapest. Its a good place for window shopping but is definitely NOT an attraction in the real sense of the word

The old Lisbon. Well one of the seven hills of Lisbon, this neighborhood is called high, being above the level of sea water, one of the famous seven hills of the city. a place where you see during the day cosmopolitan, and at night go out to the party ... Young and old will have its venue in Camões Square and then follow up by street bars and places of entertainment ... can become a bit confusing overnight high
Lisbon Shopping. Great area for shopping and walking. Use a good guide book and wander. Rua Garrett has fine shops and a shopping center. Classy

Great place for people watching.. On the side of one of the great hills in Lisbon, Chiado is full of restaurants and shops with large squares filled with tables from nearby restaurants. You can see all the other tourists around you as well as art students and local activists walking to and from their daily activities. It can get quite crowded.

The breathing heart of Lisbon. If there is one place in a big city I would like to live when I get old, It would be in Chiado (Not to old, because it is very hilly). It has a certain atmosphere and energy that cannot be found in other parts of the city, and in very few cities less alone. Visit the oldest bookshop in Lisbon (Bertrand), Have wonderful cakes in some of the cafes (not A Brasileira, becuase it is overpriced) and sit down on Largo do Carmo with a book about the Portuguese flower revolution. This is where the Portuguese defeated the dicatorship and it happened just 35 years ago! Most of all, it happened in a non-violent way, that I believe the Portuguese can be very proud of. If you come to this place in May, you will see Jacarandas blooming and their purple leafs spread all over the ground. Chiado really is a magical place.
walk to waterfront. ew loved just siting at the end of Placa Comercio and people watching while the sun set on the water and then walking back up the main street to our hotel near Rossio train
Stroll and shop. Lovely area to walk around and shop enjoy the atmosphere, sit at the oudoor cafe and have some coffee while watching the world rush by.

Best at night.... This place is alive at night..lots of activity. Great little eateries and entertainment spots. Interesting in the daytime for clothing shops and small specialty stores. It seems to shine at night.
GREAT AMBIANCE. Very hip part of town. There was always lots going on - lots of people watching, and some great cafes. We always felt very safe there at night

Upscale to inexpensive shopping, restaurants and lodging. Our apartment was in Chiado and we couldn't have picked a better neighborhood.There are tons of shopping and dining options in the area, including huge department stores, Brio organic supermarket on Rua Garret and the list goes on. Much quieter and less seedy than Barrio Alto. You are also more likely to find a local restaurant that isn't a totally overpriced tourist trap.
chic area. where you can find all the brands, shopping, cafe, restaurant and bars you wish to go. the stairs got epic nice view of the city.
Far out. Totally a cool place for many reasons. Tourists, locals melt together here and enjoy all that Lisbon has to offer.

Start here on your visit to Lisbon. The statue of Pombal is the spot were you start your visit in Lisbon.On your way towards the center and the river, you will be walking on a very beautiful boulevards, with all the famous brands on both sides of the street.
Good urban vibe. Lots of trendy shops in that area, as well as cafes and restaurants. Good atmosphere! But touristy prices. Beautiful buildings too, art nouveau style.
Worth the visit. Neighborhoods differ and this is a colorful, intriguing area to explore. It's got a heavy tourism slant but as with all large cities that is part of the life.

Enjoyable Area. The Chiado has many very good churches that are quite impressive. There are many good stores also and one can be entertained by looking at the shops. Therre are also many eating places. The FNAC Store is quite good and I was able to buy a spare memory card for my camera.
The place to be in Lisbon. This is the nicest spot to stay in Lisbon; the most central, funky stores, trendy people, and great restaurants. Very crowded, but a must do when in Lisbon.
Trendiest place in town. Best place to buy some clothes and see the earth of lisbon's lifestyle. You can go for a simple walk, enjoy a coffee at a terrace with a beautiful view too.

my favorite place in Lisbon!. the area is plenty of good and trendy restaurants, coffees, patisseries, art galleries, ateliers, museums, bookstores, designer's shops. In the Rua Garrett, main commercial street of this area is the bronze figure of the great poet Fernando Pessoa. At night street artists perform their works, like musicians, actors an so on; the atmosphere is really cool!

Great Walk!!. Chiado is a block that has 2 parts, the high one, called ALTO and the sea level called BAIXO CHIADO. On boths, you`ll see the unique architecture of Lisbon, buildings from centuries ago... Is simply gorgeous walk on those streets. Dont miss the Praça do Comercio and the Arco da Praça do Comercio. There also have all the stores you find on the mall and great r3estaurants too.Subway: BLUE LINE (Linha Azul), BAIXA CHIADO station
good shopping. lovely old streets filled with boutiques and also has a shopping center. We also found the wifi helpful at the local apple store called the M store
The classy shopping district. The main downtown Baixa area can feel a bit down at heel - so walk up to the Chiado and you'll find where chic Lisboetas go shopping. Nicer buzz.
Great for shopping!. Really nice part of town for eating and shopping. A must stop in Lisbon. Take the restaurador funicular up to Bairro Alto then walk to Chiado from there.

lovely area to hang around. lovely neighbourhood to hang around, plenty of fancy (and less fancy) shops and nice restaurants, cafes and bars. don't miss 100 ways - nicest place for a Manhattan style cocktail in a sleeky atmosphere

A BEAUTIFUL AREA. This is a charming are of Lisbon , where the locals mix with tourist , where the east meets the west and the south meets the north. The are is filled with charm and character. It is lined with restaurants and cafes and bakery and bars etc etc. It has many boutique shops where local designers show there talents. Definately a must do when in Portugal.
Chiado. Our apartment was in the heart of Chiado. Everywhere you turned there was a restaurant and shopping. Easy to get around as the metro was two blocks away from our apartment.
The place to be in Lisbon. Chiado is the coolest place to be. History meets shopping, character meets diversity. You'll find restaurants, shops and a beautiful place to be in Lisbon.
GO!. I loved everything about thiz zione at Lisbon. Old architecture, good restaurants, arts, sight seeing.. almost everything you could be looking for! Don't miss that!

Trendy and Chic!. Close to Baixa (downtown) this is one of the coolest neighborhood in Lisbon. A lot of trendy and design stores, cafes and esplanades. Make sure not missing this area while visiting Lisbon.

Fun. Chiado was a place that we used to go when we were in Lisbon. It ıs the right place when you want to have a coffe or see some tourists and have a look. the shops are also really good too, such as Hermes, Vida Porteguesa, Vista Alegre. You can find whatever you find but the shops where the known brand are sold, they are really expensive than usual.
Lovely. Quaint and a must see. Cobbled stoned streets. Artisians selling their wares. Musicians playing music along the road. Windy, hilly streets. You can't miss this!
Shopping Street. Nice, colourful but nothing typical to Lisbon. Shops which are all around Europe. Still worths seeing the steep street with classical shops..
Lively Elegant Streets. An easy walk from our hotel, we loved walking this area. Interesting stores, great music played everywhere, and good people watching.

You get it all. Nice avenues, ancient churches, monuments, big department stores, cozy places, nice restaurants, very good esplanades, street animation, you got it all in a small district, just in center of historical center of Lisbon

amazing. you can walk for hours and not see it all up and down hilly streets characters everywhere rich and poor bars to suit all tastes reataurants same fado very popular here tram if you cant or dont want to walk an experience in its self!! the real portuguese people live here rich and poor. different after midnight gay area and also more lively with some undesirable types of peop;e afe but keep your wits about you make lots of noise if you feel threatened as no one wants the attention dont be silly and waer lots of expensive jewellery no one dresses up but snare casual is nice if you so wish i personally dont do scruffy wear decent shoes for walking you can always carry a nicer pair for the evening if going to restaurant or nicer bar. when i mentioned gay area i meant no disrespect just an . observation i have gay friends. so sincerely hope no offence taken xx every area has night life and is fun and very interesting like any city look after your money and belongings people are very helpful and english is taught in all the schools so dont be shy about asking for help if needed in ordering etc:enjoy lisbon itsa wonderful place i love it and have beeb going there for over 30 years memorise your address or hotel in case you have to get a taxi reataurants willorder a taxi for you if you need just ask ENJOY

Chiado - Lisbon.. This is probably the best suburb in Lisbon. Much of Lisbon is pretty grungey, away from the touristy areas. This suburb/area is not entirely touristy, while also relatively well-maintained. Some areas, away from the touristy areas, are grotty and smelly. And most of the areas mentioned in our guide as 'shopping-areas' are dull, and there are better zones for that in most other cities. Basically our view was, the magazines over-sell Lisbon. It's okay, but there are better cities - like Madrid which is awesome.
Lively. There's a real buzz about this place but it can be a bit too touristy, restaurants touting for business etc. A lot of beggars as everywhere in Lisbon.
Busy high end shopping district. Visit the rooftop bar at the Hotel do Chiado for stunning views over Lisbon.

Decent Designer Shops. Chiado is located on the Blu Metro Line if I'm right, the area is mostly uphill in which Tram 28 passes through. Down the hill is where the designer shops are like Nike etc. There's also some restaurants along the way and at the end of the street there is the Chiado Shopping Mall, few decent shops nothing too thrilling.

Great area. Fun place to stay. Center of the action. Lots of history. You may be put off by the graffiti but we saw it as art (instead of the typical embellished names, they do full illustrations of life in Lisbon.)
Day&night. Please visit both during the day and at night! totally worth it! The same space but two completely different environments
Good. Lots to see and do and also a quiet place at night but still has lovely local restaurants.
chic chiado. Fabulous shops and stores which are well worth a browse; great shoe shops and leather goods

The City Heart. Chiado is the heart of Lisbon!
It is where all the best shops are (along with Avenida) and where everyone meets before going to Bairro Alto or Cais do Sodré for a night out.
Don't miss it!
HIgh end shopping. Bookstores, designer wear, good restaurants, charming streets, a few museums and pedestrian walkways. A must for new travelers.
Chiado district.. Great for shopping and restaurants. Convenient base for city sightseeing.
A great part of town. Full of restaurants and music comes out of every door - fado of course!
Worth a look. Like the back streets in any continental capital really. Busy, quite buzzy. Aimed at a young age group.
Fado.. We experienced a very nice show in a nice theater. Great performers in a cosy atmosphere.
Trendy and nice shopping. Without hesitation for the nice shops and reataurants
Monuments, Squares and Shops. Spreading up the hill to the west, Chiado is home to museums, theatres, historic buildings, cafes and elegant shops. A must see!
Fado in Chiado. Performances are scheduled at 7 PM each night and this is an entertaining yet affordable way to experience fado singing. Visit their website for more details.

Chiado. Chiado is a place you cannot miss in Lisbon. With many shops, restaurants and coffees is a very agited street in the city heart. There is a coffee named "Brasileira" where Fernando Pessoa, one of the best world writters, were many times.
Posh Lisbon. Very posh shops, beautiful people, nice cafés, theatres. It is worth a visit.

nice place to do some shopping. very nice shops and great to walk .
it´s a bit crowded but if you are in a good group it´s very enjoyable
Great Shopping Area. Don't miss a walk around this area. Easy to get to by Tram or Metro
A bit of everything. Great shops, walks and restaurants, very modern, layout similar to London.
Lively area !. Take the Gloria tram up here in the evening and you won't be disappointed . Lots of places to eat in a great atmosphere !
Nice shopping. Very nice neighborhood with lots of restaurants and shops, including major brands. Good place for shopping and pleasant walk during the day and the night.

Visit in March. Helpful staff and the television display was interesting. I can not remember if there was an English translation, but with art it can be as much fun guessing what some things are meant to be anyway!
Good place to walk and eat. Its the place (and Bairro Alto too) to walk during the day and night , lot of things to do , shopping and eating , nice people.

If you come to Lisbon.... ... and you don't visit Chiado, you are missing one of the most beautiful and charismatic parts of the city.Wheter you're visting for the shops or for the sights (great for street photography) you won'te regret it.It also means you don't have to go all the way to Cascais to eat an ice cream at Santinis, but that's just an added bonus.
Good and very safe area for shopping, people watching and eating!. Make sure you take elevadores there form Baixa or just a regualar escalator from Baixa/Chiado to Chiado metro
shops. nice upper end shops & lovely walk. Not far from the square & Rossio. Small mall of shops as well, but they are not as nice as the street shops.
Shoppers paradise. If you can get through this district without spending money then you're a luckier person than I. There is every imaginable fashion label and then some.
Excellent shopping area. Great stores and coffee shops on a street closed to traffic. Stroll and enjoy the people and the sights in the city center
Party!. Party area, with Fado music. Late night dining. Very lively atmosphere.
THE place to stay. This puts you near history, transportation, shopping & dining in a lovely neighborhood.

Restaurants, Bars and Lots of Hip and Funky People. This is a great neighborhood for meeting young people, having a drink in outdoor cafes and restaurants, and shopping in small shops. Much of the area bans cars so it is easy to get around as a pedestrian. While there are lots of tourists the area is also a lovely neighborhood for locals -- a really nice mix that makes you feel happy to be in Lisbon.

Interesting and vibrant part of the city. Chiado is a vibrant, historic and interesting part of central Lisbon. It is easily accessible from Baixa (by walking up the Rua do Carmo, taking the Elevador da Santa Justa or by tram 28). Baixa-Chiado metro station has an entrance/exit in the heart of Chiado, very close to the historic "A Brasileira" cafe. Be vigiliant for pickpockets, but Lisbon is certainly no worse for crime than other major European cities. I entirely disagree with the review dated 25th April 2012; there is a lot to see and do in Chiado. Have a coffee at A Brasileira or one of the other cafes, visit the shops in Rua Garrett (such as "Paris em Lisboa") and soak up the atmosphere of this special part of the city, which has recovered so well from the disastrous fire of 1988.

great shops and studios around every corner. chiado and barrio alto together are one of the places i like ot visit on one of lisbons many sunny days. there are wonderful shops and tascas (little mom and pop restuarants) as well as interesting artists and studios.
Great atmosphere. The real tradition of Lisbon, Nice cofre shops, teathers, people

city centre. The hub of the city centre. Wonderful individual shops. Try the pastries and an expresso. Metro station adjacent to area, trams run through but try exploring the surrounding streets and the waterfront.The downside is there are a lot of not very good buskers and sunglass sellers although none were threatening. Beware pick pockets and thieves. Our friend had her wallet stolen
Not much there. Touted as a great shopping area but not much there.

Lively streets.... We stayed in Chiado in an apartment off Rua Garrett. It was full of people all day and into the night. Lots of great shops, restaurants and the Santa Justa elevator. Near everything.
love the area. enchanting I loved it the streets are old stones and the trams are a treat

Deserves a visit.. The walk across Chiado lanes is a dream walk, with lots of window shopping to do in this central commercial area of Lisboa. But we had not anticipated the steep descent and then the climb back , after getting off the metro at Baixo Chiado. Tiring but fun.

Charming Neighborhood. This area deserves a walk. Interesting shops and restaurants. The Monastery do Carmo is worth a quick visit, but be prepared to see 2 mummified children if you enter the museum.
Better than San Francisco. Lots of fun but buy a day pass at a metro station...much cheaper than paying cash.
Place for night and day life. Best Place for night and day life in heart of Lisboa, walking around is great experience
Go to party party. this area is full of inexpensive bars you can go to before going to a club... the ambient is great! greatly recommended!
Chic. Chic part of town with lots of young people enjoying the outdoors.
Fado and Chiado. a little bit parisian smelling streets, listen live fado in Chiado

The heart of Lisbon. This is the center of the "old Lisbon", very charming and beautifull with a great variety of shops, restaurants and museums. Visit the Museu do Carmo one of the best in the city. Have a coffe in " A Brasileira", one of oldest café's in Lisbon right next to the Camões square. Go down the Rua do Carmo and you'll be in downtown in the Rossio square. Take your time, there's plenty to see and visit in this area. You'll love LISBON!
Central Lisbon. This is "the place." It is where most everything happens and where you can find eats galore. Central Lisbon at its best.
exquisite. Right on the edge of Bairro Alto we have the amazing Chiado, one of the ex-libris of Lisbon city. Fancy chique shops and people! Beautiful churches. A must do for any traveler!
Pretty but too touristy. so-so feeling about it - could be a neighborhood in any city - full of expensive boutiques, etc
Very enjoyable area. An enjoyable area for walking around, window shopping and people watching.
chaido. great to walk around the lovely lanes of chaido, lovely morning out stop for a coffee and a pastel de nata..

The fashion spot of Lisbon. Chiado was completely rebuilt after the great fire during the 80's, having recovered the position has the prime spot for fashion stores and upmarket commerce.Simply the best high street shopping of Lisbon and a fantastic place to see the crowds day or night.
Must see. Great neighbourhood. Lots of stores and places to hang out.

got pickpocketed. I was there last weekend. My wallet was pickpocketed from my bag while I was taking pictures on my way to Metro. We were in escalators on our way down the Metro in Baxia-Chiado station. Two guys came in between my busband and I and a girl came in front of me blocking my view. My husband noticed that my bag was opened and he pointed at one of the guy and I demanded him to get my wallet back but this guy pointed at the other guy who was on his way back up to outside again. We chased after him but he ran away too fast. In hindsight, we realised that they were all involved and highly organised and professional. Up until this point, we loved Lisbon and wanted to come back but I would never go back there again. A guy who works at the Lisbon airport said 'Welcome to Lisbon' when we mentioned about what happened. Is Lisbon that bad? I've been to many other countries famous for their crimes like Colombia but never been mugged.
Chiado is Lisbon. This is my favourite place to walk, to shop, to go with friends... It's beautiful and typical Lisbon at its best, with a beautiful architecture and friendly people.
good neighborhood. walk and enjoy it to the fullest, cafe with good coffee and pastries, good food at decent price and stores, strores and more stores
Lisboa. Is an old area from Lisbon. There was a big big fire in 198? that destryed a big stores. Now the area is Excellent. If you visit Lisbon don´t forget. Visit this area
